I modeled the ability to evaluate, prioritize, and delegate complex tasks, ensuring timely resolutions. Additionally, at **Commercial Fire**, my work managing a rolling portfolio of fire systems work orders further exemplified my skills in structuring and evaluating detailed project tasks, ensuring alignment with organizational goals.\n\n#### Narrative for MPM5300 Objective #3:\nIn my role as **Service Delivery Manager** at the **Jacksonville Transportation Authority**, I spearheaded initiatives that had profound impacts on community relations and operational efficiencies. My decisions regarding transit schedules, safety measures, and performance evaluations required a deep understanding of how individual actions could affect overall outcomes. This experience strengthened my ability to make decisions that balance immediate needs with long-term procedural impacts.\n\n#### Narrative for MPM5300 Objective #4:\nAt **Acadly**, I managed the CRM system to enhance customer interaction tracking and data accuracy, improving user satisfaction by 20% in just six months. My technical evaluation of CRM tools and their impact on user experience provided invaluable insights into optimizing project workflows. Comunit\u00e0.)\n\nSponsors \u25cf Caritas\n\n\u25cf Comune di Roma\n\n\u25cf Chefs associations and schools: Associazione Italiana Chef,\n\n\u25cf Federazione Italiana Cuochi, Italian Chefs Academy\n\n\u25cf Food distribution: Food for Good Organisation \u2013 Italy,\n\n\u25cf Glovo, Too Good to Go (TGTG)\n\n\u25cf Foundations:  ACRI, Enel Cuore Onlus, Fondazione con Il\n\nSud,\n\n\u25cf Fondazione di Roma, Fondazione Nando ed Elsa Peretti\n\n\u25cf Food establishments:\n\n\u25cf Coldiretti, EATALY Mercato Centrale Roma\n\n\u25cf Restaurants and their chefs/owners: Glass Hostaria,\n\nRistorante AGER,  Ristorante Cariplo, Ristorante Icarus,\n\nRistorante Manin\n\n\u25cf Supermarkets: Carrefour, CONAD, COOP, Tuodis\n\n\u25cf SDG2Adovcacy Hub\n\n2. KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project\n\nis to become successful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of\n\ninteracting with actors involved in and impacted by a project. It is\n\nparticularly important to a project as its completion often depends\n\non how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the\n\nCoordinator and other staff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo\n\nII who are directly involved in the daily operations and\n\nmanagement of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the\n\nMensa\u2019s feeding programme. In between are the different service\n\nproviders as well as range of volunteers involved in the project,\n\n1\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\ni.e., volunteer chefs and servers, current partners supporting the\n\nfeeding programme (i.e., Comune di Roma and the local church)\n\nand new partners providing funds and other resources mobilized\n\nfor the project and the project team.\n\nDetails on the engagement of stakeholders in the project (list,\n\nrationale for their involvement, the different \u201casks\u201d, and strategy\n\nfor their involvement/participation are outlined in the Project\n\nManagement Plan and related Annexes.\n\n4. PROJECT SCOPE\n\nPurpose of the\n\nproject\n\nTrecce Project aims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to participate\n\nin a month-long pilot event at Mensa Giovanni Paolo II in order to\n\nprepare and serve nutritious meals to the economically\n\ndisadvantaged while reducing food waste and fostering community\n\nengagement.\n\nProject objectives \u25cf Complete 13 days of dinner service\n\n\u25cf Reduce food waste and sustainably source all materials\n\n\u25cf Create a model for continued dinner service at the food\n\nkitchen\n\n\u25cf Foster community engagement\n\nHigh level\n\nrequirements\n\nRequirements needed to implement the project include (1) human\n\nresources (able project team, cooperation of the Mensa Giovanni\n\nPaolo II management and staff, volunteer chefs, student chefs,\n\nservers, partner foundations and establishments); (2) left-over\n\nfood supplies and ingredients coming from supermarkets; (3)\n\nfunding to purchase any ingredients and other materials/supplies\n\nneeded for the food service;  (4) functional/equipped and clean\n\nkitchen where food can be prepared and (5) space available where\n\nfood can be served.\n\nMain\n\ndeliverables\n\nFrom Project Management perspective\n\n\u25cf Project Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Budget\n\n\u25cf Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and WBS dictionary\n\n\u25cf Gantt Chart, Activity List, Day of Service Schedule\n\n\u25cf Project Milestone\n\n\u25cf Procurement Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Resource Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Responsibility Assignment Matrix\n\n\u25cf Stakeholder Engagement Plan, Registry and Engagement\n\nMatrix\n\n\u25cf Communications Plan\n\n\u25cf Risk Register, Risk Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\nFrom project implementation itself\n\n\u25cf Financial resources mobilized:  36,000 EUR\n\n\u25cf Human Resources mobilized\n\n\u25cb Project Team\n\n\u25cb Mensa Giovanni Paolo II staff mobilized and onboard\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of volunteers (Servers) recruited\n\n2\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of qualified chefs engaged\n\n\u25cb Partner chef associations agreeing to send student chefs to\n\nthe project\n\n\u25cb Partners supermarket, establishment and food delivery\n\nservice providers mobilized\n\n\u25cf Nutritious meals cooked and served\n\n\u25cf Economically disadvantaged people benefitting from the\n\nTrecce Project\n\n5. PROJECT LIFE CYCLE\n\nProject\n\nmanagement\n\napproach\n\nPredictive\n\nProject Phases The project phases included are: planning, recruitment, a month\n\nof service, and follow up.\n\nPlanning will require creating schedules, procurement, organizing\n\nthe food kitchen logistics, and determining KPIs for the month of\n\nservice.\n\nDuring recruitment, team members will need to gain\n\ncommitments from chefs, volunteers, and partners, which include\n\nvendors for food along with donors. The month of service is when\n\nwe implement our goal of serving nutritious meals to beneficiaries\n\nand the following month, analyze our KPIs and data to determine\n\nthe pilot program\u2019s success.\n\nMajor milestones \u25cf Gaining committed donors to fund project at 50%\n\nDeadline of 02/05/23.\n\n\u25cf Meeting all recruitment requirements\n\nDeadline of 30/6/23 for chefs and partners\n\nDeadline of 29/9/23 for volunteers\n\n\u25cf First meal of service on 02/10/23\n\n\u25cf Last meal of service on 31/10/23\n\n\u25cf All expected feedback is collected for analysis\n\nDeadline 07/11/23\n\n\u25cf Completing the follow up phase tasks\n\nDeadline of 15/11/23\n\n6. MAJOR KNOWN RISKS\n\nRisk\n\ndescription\n\n\u25cf Lack of funding for project (Medium impact)\n\n\u25cf Lack of volunteer chefs (High impact)\n\n\u25cf Food donation failure (Medium impact)\n\n\u25cf Conflict/fights among beneficiaries or team members (Low\n\nimpact)\n\n\u25cf Embezzlement of project funds (Rare/Negligible impact)\n\n\u25cf Littering (Low impact)\n\n\u25cf Food poisoning and allergies (High impact)\n\n7. ASSUMPTIONS AND CONSTRAINTS\n\nAssumptions \u25cf Sponsor supermarkets will donate food items to project\n\n\u25cf Chefs will be available to participate in the project\n\n\u25cf Project will attract funding\n\n\u25cf Project funds will be utilized for the intended purpose\n\n\u25cf Meals will be nutritious and healthy for beneficiaries\n\n3\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cf Financial sponsors will remit agreed upon funds should need\n\narise\n\n\u25cf Groceries and cooking materials will be readily available\n\nConstraints \u25cf Unavailability of chefs\n\n\u25cf Donation failure from Partner Supermarkets\n\n\u25cf Lack of funding for project\n\n\u25cf No attention and smooth resolution to conflict\n\n\u25cf Poor quality meals/food poisoning and allergy attacks\n\n\u25cf Embezzlement of project funds\n\n8.APPROVED FINANCIAL RESOURCES\n\nProject budget\n\n9. PROJECT APPROVAL REQUIREMENTS\n\nProject approval\n\nrequirements\n\nAchieving the following represents project success. OLIVEROS\n\nCatelijne RIBBINK\n\nPROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nTRECCE Project\n\n1\n\n\n\nRome, 23 January 2023\n\nVERSION\n\nVersion\n\n#\n\nRealized by Revision\n\ndate\n\nApproved\n\nby\n\nApproval\n\ndate\n\nRationale\n\n1.0 MGH 09/12/2022 OO 10/12/2022 First draft of PMP\n\n1.1 AL 20/01/2023 MGH 20/01/2023 Edit to Cost management\n\n1.2 OO 20/01/2023 MM 20/01/2023 Edit to Stakeholder\n\nengagement\n\n1.3 OO 21/01/2023 CR/MGH 22/01/2023 Finalizing PMP\n\n1.4 AL 23/01/2023 Finalizing PMP\n\nPage 2 of 25\n\n\n\nTABLE OF CONTENTS\n\nSummary\n\n1 INTRODUCTION 4\n\n2 SCOPE MANAGEMENT 6\n\n3 COST MANAGEMENT 11\n\n4 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT 12\n\n5 PROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT 13\n\n6 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT 14\n\n7 RISK MANAGEMENT AND REGISTER 15\n\n8 STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT 16\n\nAPPENDIX A: PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN APPROVAL 21\n\nAPPENDIX B: ANNEX DIRECTORY 22\n\nAPPENDIX C: GLOSSARY 24\n\nAPPENDIX D: EXTERNAL DOCUMENTATION AND RESOURCES 25\n\nPage 3 of 25\n\n\n\n1 INTRODUCTION\n\n1.1 PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nThe following project management plan was completed for the project titled \u201cTrecce\u201d. It\n\nwas developed based on acceptance of the related Project Charter and defines how this\n\nproject will be executed, monitored, controlled, and closed. This PMP is addressed to all\n\nstakeholders, including the management team, all sponsors, and the project team. Trecce\n\naims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to take part in a month-long pilot event at Mensa\n\nGiovanni Paolo II to offer nutritious meals to the economically disadvantaged while\n\nreducing food waste and fostering community engagement. The name Trecce, meaning\n\nbraids in Italian, derives from the intertwined connection the kitchen, chefs, and\n\ncommunity will have during this project.\n\nPage 4 of 25\n\n\n\n1.2 ASSUMPTIONS AND CONSTRAINTS\n\nThe Assumption and Constraints matrix is a very crucial component of the Risk\n\nManagement Plan. It is very important in forecasting, which is important in building a\n\nproject vision, and identifying project deliverables. Constraints on the other hand could\n\nserve as potential risks if not well managed. The matrix can serve as a guide to the\n\nProject Management Team in identifying all known risks.\n\nPlease refer to the Assumption and Constraints matrix for a detailed description of all\n\nregistered project assumptions and constraints. The matrix can be found in the Risk\n\nManagement Plan folder.\n\nSee Annex 1:  Assumption and constraints\n\nPage 5 of 25\n\n\n\n2 SCOPE MANAGEMENT\n\n2.1 REQUIREMENTS DOCUMENTATION\n\nThe requirements of Trecce include all needs to lead to a successful food service for\n\nbeneficiaries. These include acquiring the needed stakeholders, having an adequate\n\nlocation for food preparation and service, providing schedules to stakeholders, and the\n\nmeans to analyze program success.\n\n2.2 REQUIREMENTS TRACEABILITY MATRIX\n\nSee Annex 2: Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\n2.3 WORK BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE\n\nThe Trecce Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) categorizes all work needed to complete\n\nthe project and represents 100% of the scope. The WBS is broken down into the\n\nfollowing format:\n\n1. Project Management\n\n1.1. Execution\n\n1.1.1. Communication Plan Execution\n\n1.1.2. Project Work Execution\n\n1.1.3. Risk Response Execution\n\n1.2. Monitoring &amp; Controlling\n\n1.2.1. Risk Monitoring\n\n1.2.2. Schedule &amp; Milestone Controlling\n\n1.2.3. Cost monitoring\n\n1.3. Close\n\n1.3.1. Project Close Documents\n\n1.3.2. Project Close\n\n2. Planning\n\n2.1. Procurement\n\n2.1.1. Food/service supplies\n\n2.1.2. Transportation for food/materials\n\n2.2. Schedule\n\n2.2.1. Chef schedule\n\n2.2.2. Volunteer schedule\n\n2.2.3. Timeline for day of service\n\n2.3. Location\n\n2.3.1. Site visit to kitchen\n\n2.3.2. Kitchen space checklist\n\n2.3.3. Dining space checklist\n\n2.4. KPIs\n\nPage 6 of 25\n\n\n\n3. Recruitment\n\n3.1. Chefs\n\n3.1.1. Chef pre-selection meetings\n\n3.1.2. Chef partnership agreements\n\n3.1.3. Chef confirmation\n\n3.1.4. Pre-month-of-service meetings with chefs\n\n3.2. Partners\n\n3.2.1. Partner pre-selection meetings\n\n3.2.2. Partner agreements\n\n3.2.3. Confirmation of partners\n\n3.2.4. Partner pre-month-of-service meetings\n\n3.3. Volunteers\n\n3.3.1. Development of recruitment/advertising materials\n\n3.3.2. Marketing launch\n\n3.3.3. Volunteer sign up period\n\n3.3.4. Volunteer roles determination\n\n3.4. Team Building Event\n\n4. Month of Service\n\n4.1. Food Coordination\n\n4.1.1. Donation food delivery\n\n4.1.2. Menu selection\n\n4.1.3. Purchased food delivery\n\n4.2. Volunteer coordination\n\n4.2.1. Kitchen volunteer coordination\n\n4.2.2. Service area volunteer coordination\n\n4.3. Site coordination\n\n4.3.1. Kitchen coordination\n\n4.3.2. Food service area coordination\n\n4.4. Food Service\n\n5. Post Service Month Evaluation\n\n5.1. Feedback\n\n5.1.1. Chef feedback meetings\n\n5.1.2. Volunteer feedback via surveys\n\n5.1.3. Beneficiaries feedback via verbal questions\n\n5.1.4. Partner feedback meetings\n\n5.2. Data Analyzation\n\n5.2.1. KPI analyzation\n\n5.2.2. Feedback analyzation\n\n5.2.3. Feedback report\n\n5.3. Milestone Review Meeting\n\nSee Annex 3:  WBS Dictionary\n\nSee Annex 4: ProjectLibre WBS\n\n2.3.1 CHANGE MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIf any stakeholder believes a change to the project scope or schedule is necessary, they\n\nPage 7 of 25\n\n\n\nwill be required to complete the Trecce Change Request Form. Once completed, they will\n\nneed to email this form to the project management team, indicated in the project charter.\n\nAt that time, the project management team will review the request and determine if the\n\nchange is approved or denied, completing any research on the change as needed. If\n\napproved, the project management team will be responsible for informing the affected\n\nstakeholders and updating any related project documents such as the schedule, activity\n\nlist, risk register, responsibility assignment matrix, or any document the PM team deems\n\naffected. If the request is denied, the PM team should respond to the stakeholder who\n\nrequested the change, indicating the reason for the denial.\n\nSee Annex 5: Change Request Form\n\n2.4 PROJECT SCHEDULE MANAGEMENT\n\nThe project schedule has been broken into the following phases: planning, recruitment, a\n\nmonth of service, and a post-service-month evaluation. The timeline for each phase\n\ndiffers due to project work needs, the man hours needed to complete the phase, observed\n\nholidays in Rome, and being mindful of our external stakeholders&#x27; schedules.\n\nDuring the planning phase, the main tasks will include procurement of materials,\n\nscheduling for the month of service, and food kitchen logistics. The timeline for this\n\nphase starts three months before the month of service and will last until the end of\n\nSeptember. As chefs and partners will dictate planning details, a lot of the work in this\n\nphase will occur after recruitment.\n\nThe recruitment of partners has already started in September of 2022. As Trecce\n\nrelies on donors to fund the project, it is important to receive around 50% of our\n\ndonation goal before the kickoff meeting on May 2, 2023. Therefore, we felt the urgency\n\nto start requesting donations as soon as possible. The recruitment of chefs will start at\n\nthe project kickoff and last until June 30, 2023. Holding this recruitment early on allows\n\nfor the most preparation of schedules and planning. Volunteers will start to be recruited\n\nonce marketing materials are launched and can sign up all the way up to the month of\n\nservice.\n\nThe timeline for the month of service includes all activities needed to conduct a\n\ndinner service successfully. Dinner service days include Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and\n\nPage 8 of 25\n\n\n\nThursdays. The food delivery will take place on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays,\n\none day before the meal service, to ensure our chefs have time to properly inspect the\n\ndonated food, determine a menu, and request any food items that need to be bought to\n\ncomplete the meal.\n\nFor the post-service-month evaluation, the goal is to understand whether or not this\n\npilot program has been successful or not. The schedule includes time to hear the\n\nopinions of chefs, partners, volunteers, and beneficiaries to understand the program&#x27;s\n\npros and cons. Once all data is collected, the project management team will analyze this\n\ndata and compile a report stating their opinion.\n\n2.4.1 ACTIVITY LIST AND ATTRIBUTES\n\nThe Trecce activity list encompasses all activities that must be completed in order for\n\nthe project to be successful. These were developed from the Work Breakdown Structure\n\nand should include 100% of the project work. Included in the activity list are the activity\n\nID, activity Name, WBS ID, predecessor and successor activities, logical relationship\n\nindicators, leads/lags, the imposed deadline, and the location where the activity will take\n\nplace. The project management team is responsible for monitoring the activity list and\n\nmaking any necessary updates during the project lifecycle.\n\nSee Annex 7: Activity List\n\n2.4.2 MILESTONE LIST\n\nMilestone Deadline\n\nGaining committed donors to fund project at 50% 02/05/23\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for chefs. 30/06/2023\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for partners 30/06/2023\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for volunteers 29/09/23\n\nThe first meal service 02/10/2023\n\nThe last meal service 31/10/2023\n\nAll expected feedback is collected for analysis 07/11/2023\n\nCompleting the follow-up phase tasks 15/11/2023\n\nSee Annex 8: Milestones\n\n2.4.3 PROJECT SCHEDULE\n\nSee Annex 6: ProjectLibre Gantt Chart\n\nSee Annex 7: Activity list\n\nPage 9 of 25\n\nhttps://drive.google.com/file/d/1KEQKckZ4wXzWammYTsR6mjKu65fmn_an/view?usp=share_link\n\n\nSee Annex 3:  WBS Dictionary\n\nSee Annex 21: Day of Service Timeline\n\nPage 10 of 25\n\n\n\n3 COST MANAGEMENT\n\n3.1 BUDGET &amp; SCHEDULE OF EXPENSES\n\nAt the start of planning we assume that 50% of the project funding has been secured.\n\nFundraising activities will continue throughout the project. In addition, as this is a\n\ncharitable endeavor, the project management team has agreed to donate 60% of their\n\nsalary toward the project. The schedule of funding partners with donation amount, along\n\nwith a complete schedule of expenses and contingency funding amounts to be found in\n\nthe annex.\n\nSee Annex 9: Budget and Schedule of expenses\n\nPage 11 of 25\n\n\n\n4 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT\n\n4.1 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT PLAN OVERVIEW\n\nThe Trecce Procurement Management Plan aims to define the project\u2019s procurement and\n\nquality management process. The plan will set out the procurement and quality\n\nmanagement guidelines, define the risks associated with the procurement and quality\n\nmanagement strategy, and suggest the strategy for mitigating those risks. Specifically,\n\nthe Procurement Management Plan will define the following:\n\n\u25cf Project procurement partners and donating partners\n\n\u25cf Quality and procurement work breakdown structures (WBSs)\n\n\u25cf Establishing partner deliverables and deadlines\n\n\u25cf Which items are to be procured via direct purchase, pricing, and timelines\n\n\u25cf Determining material costs \n\n\u25cf Risks associated with procurement management\n\n\u25cf How procurement risks will be mitigated\n\n\u25cf How procurement is coordinated with project scope, budget, and schedule \n\n\u25cf Inventory and Quality Assessment Log Template\n\n\u25cf Quality management criteria\n\n\u25cf Specify all constraints pertaining to procurement\n\n\u25cf Performance metrics for procurement activities\n\nPlease refer to Annex 10 for the complete Trecce Procurement and Quality Management\n\nPlan.\n\nSee Annex 10: Trecce - Procurement and Quality Management Plan\n\nSee Annex 11: Inventory and Quality Assessment Log\n\nPage 12 of 25\n\n\n\n5 PROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT\n\nThe Resource Management Plan defines the approach to identify, acquire, and manage\n\nthe human and physical resources needed for the Trecce project. Resources are key\n\ncomponents of any project. Therefore, successfully identifying all the required human\n\nand material resources required for this endeavor is fundamental. The Resource\n\nManagement Plan also encompasses the Team Charter, a key document that outlines\n\nteam members&#x27; roles and responsibilities, team values, agreements, and operating\n\nguidelines. Please refer to the Resource Management Plan for a detailed description of all\n\nresources identified, how they will be managed and utilized for project success, and all\n\nnecessary information on the Team Charter.\n\nSee Annex 12:  Project Resource Management Plan\n\n5.1 RESPONSIBILITY ASSIGNMENT MATRIX\n\nThe Responsibility Assignment Matrix is a key component of the Resource Management\n\nPlan, which is required to inform all project team members on the assignment of project\n\ntasks/activities. This matrix details each project work activity, clearly indicating the\n\nhuman resource responsible of performing specific project activity/s, who is accountable\n\nfor its success or failure, who is to be consulted before the activity is conducted, and who\n\nis to be informed. The Trecce Project Team chose the RASCI matrix as opposed to the\n\nRASCI matrix because of the support component in the former. The support component\n\nis vital to this project as this is a social endeavor based on humanitarian ideals; therefore,\n\nteamwork, collaboration, and support are highly emphasized for all stakeholders\n\ninvolved to boost the chances of project success. Please refer to the Responsibility\n\nAssignment Matrix for a detailed description of all project activities and assignments.\n\nSee Annex 13: RASCI Matrix\n\nPage 13 of 25\n\n\n\n6 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT\n\nCommunication is critical in any project, not only for involving the stakeholders and\n\nincreasing stakeholder engagement but also to avoid potential mistakes caused by\n\nmiscommunication. For this project, we have established the following communicational\n\npillars that played a central role in our communication plan: transparency, to create a\n\nsafe space, clarity, and a safe approach to handling personal information. With these\n\npillars in mind, we have tried to communicate successfully with our target audience and\n\nall involved stakeholders. We have used a tailored approach to communicate with\n\nstakeholders, partners, volunteers, etc. This is accomplished through using different\n\ncommunication tools per group in order to communicate as well as possible. All the\n\nspecific information on which tactics and tools were used per group and a more detailed\n\nexplanation of our communication plan can be found in the following document.\n\nSee Annex 14: Communications Plan\n\n6.1 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIn the communication matrix, we have provided an overview of the outgoing\n\ncommunication stream. The table includes the information we provide, the recipient, the\n\ncommunication method, the frequency but also the person in charge of our project team.\n\nThe table also includes the assumptions and constraints we foresee for the information\n\nprovided.\n\nSee Annex 15: Communication Matrix\n\nSee Annex 22: Communication Pillars\n\nPage 14 of 25\n\n\n\n7 RISK MANAGEMENT AND REGISTER\n\nA project risk is any foreseen or unknown issue that can potentially have a positive or\n\nnegative impact on the project. The Trecce Project Team successfully worked with the\n\nrelevant stakeholders in identifying all known project risks. Mitigation strategies have\n\nbeen clearly defined in the risk matrix. Likewise, the recommended contingency action\n\nwill be utilized should the risk occur. Contingency plans have been put in place to\n\naddress any future unforeseen risk or residual risks. The importance of this matrix to\n\nproject success cannot be overemphasized, as risks can be quantified and calculated to\n\ndetermine the financial impact they could pose to the project. This tool is vital in tracking\n\nand managing all risks to mitigate, eliminate, or exploit any risk.\n\nSee Annex 16: Risk Register\n\n7.1 ISSUE LOG\n\nThe Issue Log is crucial during project execution to track and document all issues\n\nthat may arise during the course of the project. This matrix is important in detailing and\n\nassigning issues to individuals and setting a due date for the successful resolution of\n\nissues. This document will help the Trecce Project Team to monitor, assign, and solve\n\nissues before they potentially grow into constraints or risks for the project.\n\nSee Annex 17:  Issue Log matrix\n\nPage 15 of 25\n\n\n\n8 STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project is to become\n\nsuccessful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of interacting with actors involved in\n\nand impacted by a project. It is particularly important to a project as its completion often\n\ndepends on how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the Coordinator and other\n\nstaff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo II who are directly involved in the daily\n\noperations and management of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the Mensa\u2019s feeding program.\n\nIn between are the different service providers as well as range of volunteers involved in\n\nthe project, i.e., volunteer chefs and servers, current partners supporting the feeding\n\nprogram (i.e., Comune di Roma and the local church) and new partners providing funds\n\nand other resources mobilized for the project and the project team.\n\nPage 16 of 25\n\n\n\n8.1 PROJECT TRECCE KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nMensa Caritas Diocesana &quot;Giovanni Paolo II&quot; Coordinator and staff. Carlo\n\nVirtu is Mensa&#x27;s Coordinator. As the key decision maker in Mensa, his leadership and\n\nbuy-in are crucial to successfully rolling out the project. At Mensa, he is responsible for\n\nCoordinating all activities of the Food Kitchen, reporting, and liaison with stakeholders.\n\nHe is ably supported by a team composed of an Assistant Coordinator (Simon\n\nEsuperanzi), an Administrative Officer (Massimo Ceccarelli), and a Cleaning/\n\nOrganization Staff (Brenda Longo). This team, in particular its Coordinator, is contacted\n\nand consulted right from the very start of the project where the Trecce Project concept\n\nwas presented. After listening to and taking into account their inputs, the overall project\n\nidea was revised, and from which the overall work plan and budget were developed. The\n\nteam is obviously very much involved in the pilot project implementation and in\n\nevaluating its effectiveness after completing the pilot phase. It is important that\n\ninteraction with this group is carried out in person, with clear agreements documented in\n\nwriting to avoid any misunderstanding and miscommunication.\n\nComune di Roma and Caritas Roma. As the two organizations supporting the\n\ncurrent feeding program at Mensa, it is important that the Trecce project builds on the\n\nongoing program they currently support. As with the Mensa team, both Comune and\n\nCaritas are contacted and consulted right from the very start of the project, where the\n\nTrecce Project concept was presented. Their inputs and suggestions are integrated into\n\nthe design of the project, and their full support moving forward was solicited. The Project\n\nteam assures the Comune and Caritas that the Trecce Project will build on the current\n\nfeeding program that they are supporting and that any changes to be made are only to\n\nimprove it. Regular and open communication, both verbal and written, takes place\n\nregularly, with meeting agreements documented.\n\nProject beneficiaries. The project is designed with the economically disadvantaged in\n\nmind, i.e., hundreds of people who rely on free meals provided by Mensa. But free meals\n\ndo not need to be less nutritious. Trecce Project is all about serving nutritious meals\n\nprepared by volunteer chefs/student chefs. Feedback from the beneficiaries will be\n\nsolicited verbally during or right after each meal service.\n\nPage 17 of 25\n\n\n\nFood transport service provider. Transport provider LogTech SRL is mobilized to\n\nensure timely delivery of food items/ingredients, either donated or purchased. They are\n\nbriefed as regards the project, emphasizing the critical role they play in avoiding delays\n\nand smooth execution of daily plans.\n\nToo Good To Go, Glovo, and Food for Good. These partners are all engaged in\n\nreducing food waste and in making nutritious food accessible. Trecce project partners\n\nwith them to provide ready meals to the Trecce project in case of insufficient meals\n\nduring project execution. Also, should there be excess food items prepared, they are also\n\nmobilized to deliver to other individuals or other charities in Rome. Terms of\n\ncollaboration with these partners are spelled out in a Partnership Agreement which is\n\ndiscussed and agreed upon with them following the presentation and discussion of the\n\nTrecce Project prior to its kickoff.\n\nPartner chefs, Culinary Schools, and Chef associations. There is no shortage of\n\nfood practitioners in Rome. Foremost of these are various restaurant chefs, culinary\n\nschools, and chef associations in the city. With thousands of members among\n\nprofessional chefs and restaurateurs (in the case of associations) and future chefs and\n\nteachers (in the case of culinary schools), these establishments is a rich pool of volunteer\n\nchefs, teachers, and students whose values and passion are fully aligned with the\n\nphilosophy of the Trecce project, i.e., making nutritious food available while reducing\n\nfood loss and waste. Chef associations are solicited to entice and encourage their member\n\nchefs to volunteer for the program and cook meals for the project beneficiaries.\n\nRestaurant chefs who are not members of any of the associations are also approached to\n\nvolunteer as well. In the case of culinary schools, a special arrangement is explored\n\nwhere the involvement of the culinary students in the project can be counted and\n\nvalidated as part of their community immersion and practices within their own\n\ncurriculum. The Trecce Project will be pitched to these establishments and individuals.\n\nTerms of collaboration are spelled out in a Partnership Agreement that will be discussed\n\nand signed among the parties concerned.\n\nPartner foundations. Foundations are private entities serving public goals. Prospect\n\nresearch was carried out to identify private foundations in Rome whose mission and\n\nobjectives are aligned with the Trecce Project objectives. The various foundations\n\nPage 18 of 25\n\n\n\nidentified as partners for the project operate in Rome, promoting and supporting causes\n\nsuch as community welfare and social inclusion (e.g., ACRI), families and people in\n\neconomic difficulty, migrants and refugees (e.g., Enel Cuore Onlus), health and aid to the\n\nunderprivileged (e.g., Fondazione di Roma), and food security (e.g., Coldiretti). These\n\ninstitutions will be requested, following a pitch for support, to contribute financial\n\nresources to cover the cost of ingredients (should there not be sufficient leftovers from\n\nthe restaurant of volunteer chefs) and project operations (transport, publicity, etc.).\n\nPartner supermarkets. Italy has a law that will make supermarkets donate more of\n\ntheir waste food to charities. The Trecce project will build on this law by soliciting\n\npartner supermarkets (Conad, Coop, Carrefour, Tuodis) to donate unsold perishable\n\nitems (e.g., fruits, vegetables, and other ingredients) that are still suitable for\n\nconsumption through the project. This contributes to minimizing their waste while\n\nimproving their community involvement and enhancing their corporate social\n\nresponsibility. The supermarket branches identified are those within close vicinity of the\n\nMensa in order to minimize transport but also for further visibility of the supermarket as\n\nwell. The Trecce project will be presented to the management of the supermarket\n\nbranches identified. The terms and conditions of their involvement are specified in a\n\nPartnership Agreement that is discussed, agreed upon, and signed by concerned parties.\n\nVolunteer servers. Trecce Project will rely on a set of volunteer servers of different\n\nprofiles building on their high level of social and ecological awareness and sense of\n\nservice (Profile 1); on their interest to spend available and gain insights from their\n\nexperience while at the same time giving them a sense of worth through this community\n\nengagement work (Profile 2); and on their curiosity to discover and know the other side\n\nof Rome while giving them an opportunity to be part of a community. They will be\n\nrecruited to augment human power needs to help in the preparation and cleaning of the\n\nvenue, keep order during meal service, and accompany/talk with the beneficiaries. As\n\noutlined in the Communication Plan, teasers/flyers with details on how to volunteer are\n\nprepared and posted around Rome. A briefing/orientation session will be organized and\n\nconducted. Volunteer Agreement/Consent that spells out the work that needs to be\n\ncarried out, roles and responsibilities as volunteer servers, as well as service schedules,\n\nare prepared, presented, and discussed with the volunteers.\n\nPage 19 of 25\n\n\n\nVisibility/outreach partners (SDG2Hub, Eataly, Mercato Centrale Roma).\n\nTrecce Project also aspires to inspire other cities to come up with similar initiatives. To\n\nthis end, partners with advocacy groups (e.g., SDG2Hub) will be mobilized for further\n\nvisibility. Likewise, the participation of establishments with high potential for local\n\noutreach for volunteers inc. stall owners/cooks, and individual donors (e.g., Eataly,\n\nMercato Centrale Roma) will be sought to contribute to the project as well in terms of\n\nproviding space to display initiative&#x27;s poster (if appropriate); providing connections to\n\nsolicit chef volunteers; but also to collect any unused ingredients from the restaurant(s)\n\noperating in their establishment. As with other partners, the involvement of these\n\ninstitutions will be requested, following a pitch for support process.\n\nAcross all stakeholders involved, feedback shall be solicited in various ways (via\n\nsurvey, phone, or in-person conversation) for further improvement as well as to assess\n\npossible follow-up/next steps. Also, issues and disagreements, should they arise, shall be\n\nsettled amicably by the parties concerned. Finally, the contribution of all partners is\n\nacknowledged and recognized through posters displayed during meal service (e.g., \u201cThis\n\nevening\u2019s/week&#x27;s meal is supported/brought to you by Partner XYZ\u201d).\n\nThe detailed list of these stakeholders, the rationale for their involvement, and their\n\nspecific involvement/participation in the project are presented as Annexes of this\n\ndocument.\n\n8.2 STAKEHOLDER REGISTER, STAKEHOLDER MAP, STAKEHOLDER\n\nENGAGEMENT ASSESSMENT MATRIX AND STAKEHOLDER\n\nENGAGEMENT PLAN\n\nSee Annex 18: STH Register\n\nSee Annex 19: STH Engagement Assess. Matrix\n\nSee Annex 20: STH Engagement Plan\n\nPage 20 of 25\n\n\n\nAPPENDIX A: PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN APPROVAL\n\nThe undersigned certifies that I have examined the plan of the Project &lt;Project name&gt;\n\nand confirms that I approve the approach presented. "\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nJTA Presentation notes.pptx\n\n\nJACKSONVILLE TRANSPORTATION \nAUTHORITY\n\nJacksonville\nTransportation\nAuthority\n\nAlexis Lindsay  \n\nService Delivery Manager\n\nThe first 90 days\u2026\n\n\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nGoal Setting Criteria\n\n2\n\n\u2022 Realistic\n\u2022 Achievable\n\u2022 Dynamic\n\u2022 Hyper-efficient\n\u2022 Productive\n\n  \n\n\n\n3\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nExcellence In Execution\n\nCORE VALUES\n\u2022 Safe Work Environment\n\u2022 Professional Excellence\n\u2022 Personal Integrity\n\u2022 Fiscal Responsibility\n\u2022 Accountability \n\u2022 Transparency \n\u2022 Continuous Improvement\n\n\n\n4\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nThe First 30 Days\n\n\u2022 Complete all training\n\ufffd Safety Training \n\ufffd Operating Rules and Regulations\n\ufffd Organizational/Departmental Orientation\n\n\u2022 Ride roundtrip on all routes in service area\n\u2022 Get to know your team\n\u2022 Study and pass all Florida Commercial \n\nDriver\u2019s License Class \u201cB\u201d with  Passenger \nendorsement written exams\n\n\n\n\u2022 Implement guidelines and operating \nprocedures to ensure superior service to \ncustomers including safety and on-time \nperformance of transit operations.\n\n\u2022 Maintain performance and attendance \ninformation for each team member.\n\ufffd Review the attendance and performance evaluations of all \n\ndirect/indirect reports.\n\ufffd Job shadow all direct reports at least once.\n\ufffd Review and ensure all direct reports are in compliance with \n\nmandatory training.\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nThe First 60 Days\n\n\n\n\u2022 Process passenger complaints and take \ncorrective action.\n\n\u2022 Coordinate with JTA Command Center \npersonnel and operations supervisors to \nresolve questions about service delays or \nroute detours and changes.\n\n\u2022 Address all JTA bus stop and shelter issues \nand refer to appropriate staff for a resolution.\n\n\u2022 Obtain a Florida CDL Class \u201cB\u201d learners permit \nand begin practicing for the road test.\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nThe First 60 Days (cont\u2019d)\n\n\n\n\u2022 Identify and report JTA bus operator rule \nviolations and provide corrective coaching, \ncounseling, and disciplinary actions.\n\n\u2022 Respond to accidents, passenger disturbances \nand other events and resolve passenger and \nJTA Bus Operator problems.\n\n\u2022 Act as a community liaison throughout \nservice area and act as the liaison between \nOperations Supervisors and other JTA team \nmembers.\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nThe First 90 Days\n\n\n\n\u2022 Assist with special event organization and \nexecution (e.g., stadium shuttles, special \nservice requests, promotional outreach, new \nservice adjustments, public hearings etc.).\n\n\u2022 Coordinate required special projects and \nassigning tasks while overseeing transit \nsupervisors as needed.\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY PROJECT DETAILS\n\nProject Name Trecce (Cucina. Cuoco. Comunit\u00e0.)\n\nSponsors \u25cf Caritas\n\n\u25cf Comune di Roma\n\n\u25cf Chefs associations and schools: Associazione Italiana Chef,\n\n\u25cf Federazione Italiana Cuochi, Italian Chefs Academy\n\n\u25cf Food distribution: Food for Good Organisation \u2013 Italy,\n\n\u25cf Glovo, Too Good to Go (TGTG)\n\n\u25cf Foundations:  ACRI, Enel Cuore Onlus, Fondazione con Il\n\nSud,\n\n\u25cf Fondazione di Roma, Fondazione Nando ed Elsa Peretti\n\n\u25cf Food establishments:\n\n\u25cf Coldiretti, EATALY Mercato Centrale Roma\n\n\u25cf Restaurants and their chefs/owners: Glass Hostaria,\n\nRistorante AGER,  Ristorante Cariplo, Ristorante Icarus,\n\nRistorante Manin\n\n\u25cf Supermarkets: Carrefour, CONAD, COOP, Tuodis\n\n\u25cf SDG2Adovcacy Hub\n\n2. PROJECT MANAGEMENT TEAM\n\nProject Manager Trecce Project Team\n\nProject\n\nManagement\n\nTeam\n\n\u25cf Mary Grace Hatcher, Responsible for project scope and\n\nschedule management\n\n\u25cf Alexis Lindsay,  Responsible for project quality and cost\n\nmanagement, and conflict management.\n\n\u25cf Michael P. Mendy, Responsible for project resource and risk\n\nmanagement\n\n\u25cf Oliver Oliveros, Responsible for project stakeholder\n\nengagement\n\n\u25cf Catelijne Ribbink, Responsible for project communications\n\nmanagement\n\n3. KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project\n\nis to become successful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of\n\ninteracting with actors involved in and impacted by a project. It is\n\nparticularly important to a project as its completion often depends\n\non how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the\n\nCoordinator and other staff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo\n\nII who are directly involved in the daily operations and\n\nmanagement of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the\n\nMensa\u2019s feeding programme. In between are the different service\n\nproviders as well as range of volunteers involved in the project,\n\n1\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\ni.e., volunteer chefs and servers, current partners supporting the\n\nfeeding programme (i.e., Comune di Roma and the local church)\n\nand new partners providing funds and other resources mobilized\n\nfor the project and the project team.\n\nDetails on the engagement of stakeholders in the project (list,\n\nrationale for their involvement, the different \u201casks\u201d, and strategy\n\nfor their involvement/participation are outlined in the Project\n\nManagement Plan and related Annexes.\n\n4. PROJECT SCOPE\n\nPurpose of the\n\nproject\n\nTrecce Project aims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to participate\n\nin a month-long pilot event at Mensa Giovanni Paolo II in order to\n\nprepare and serve nutritious meals to the economically\n\ndisadvantaged while reducing food waste and fostering community\n\nengagement.\n\nProject objectives \u25cf Complete 13 days of dinner service\n\n\u25cf Reduce food waste and sustainably source all materials\n\n\u25cf Create a model for continued dinner service at the food\n\nkitchen\n\n\u25cf Foster community engagement\n\nHigh level\n\nrequirements\n\nRequirements needed to implement the project include (1) human\n\nresources (able project team, cooperation of the Mensa Giovanni\n\nPaolo II management and staff, volunteer chefs, student chefs,\n\nservers, partner foundations and establishments); (2) left-over\n\nfood supplies and ingredients coming from supermarkets; (3)\n\nfunding to purchase any ingredients and other materials/supplies\n\nneeded for the food service;  (4) functional/equipped and clean\n\nkitchen where food can be prepared and (5) space available where\n\nfood can be served.\n\nMain\n\ndeliverables\n\nFrom Project Management perspective\n\n\u25cf Project Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Budget\n\n\u25cf Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and WBS dictionary\n\n\u25cf Gantt Chart, Activity List, Day of Service Schedule\n\n\u25cf Project Milestone\n\n\u25cf Procurement Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Resource Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Responsibility Assignment Matrix\n\n\u25cf Stakeholder Engagement Plan, Registry and Engagement\n\nMatrix\n\n\u25cf Communications Plan\n\n\u25cf Risk Register, Risk Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\nFrom project implementation itself\n\n\u25cf Financial resources mobilized:  36,000 EUR\n\n\u25cf Human Resources mobilized\n\n\u25cb Project Team\n\n\u25cb Mensa Giovanni Paolo II staff mobilized and onboard\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of volunteers (Servers) recruited\n\n2\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of qualified chefs engaged\n\n\u25cb Partner chef associations agreeing to send student chefs to\n\nthe project\n\n\u25cb Partners supermarket, establishment and food delivery\n\nservice providers mobilized\n\n\u25cf Nutritious meals cooked and served\n\n\u25cf Economically disadvantaged people benefitting from the\n\nTrecce Project\n\n5. PROJECT LIFE CYCLE\n\nProject\n\nmanagement\n\napproach\n\nPredictive\n\nProject Phases The project phases included are: planning, recruitment, a month\n\nof service, and follow up.\n\nPlanning will require creating schedules, procurement, organizing\n\nthe food kitchen logistics, and determining KPIs for the month of\n\nservice.\n\nDuring recruitment, team members will need to gain\n\ncommitments from chefs, volunteers, and partners, which include\n\nvendors for food along with donors. The month of service is when\n\nwe implement our goal of serving nutritious meals to beneficiaries\n\nand the following month, analyze our KPIs and data to determine\n\nthe pilot program\u2019s success.\n\nMajor milestones \u25cf Gaining committed donors to fund project at 50%\n\nDeadline of 02/05/23.\n\n\u25cf Meeting all recruitment requirements\n\nDeadline of 30/6/23 for chefs and partners\n\nDeadline of 29/9/23 for volunteers\n\n\u25cf First meal of service on 02/10/23\n\n\u25cf Last meal of service on 31/10/23\n\n\u25cf All expected feedback is collected for analysis\n\nDeadline 07/11/23\n\n\u25cf Completing the follow up phase tasks\n\nDeadline of 15/11/23\n\n6. MAJOR KNOWN RISKS\n\nRisk\n\ndescription\n\n\u25cf Lack of funding for project (Medium impact)\n\n\u25cf Lack of volunteer chefs (High impact)\n\n\u25cf Food donation failure (Medium impact)\n\n\u25cf Conflict/fights among beneficiaries or team members (Low\n\nimpact)\n\n\u25cf Embezzlement of project funds (Rare/Negligible impact)\n\n\u25cf Littering (Low impact)\n\n\u25cf Food poisoning and allergies (High impact)\n\n7. ASSUMPTIONS AND CONSTRAINTS\n\nAssumptions \u25cf Sponsor supermarkets will donate food items to project\n\n\u25cf Chefs will be available to participate in the project\n\n\u25cf Project will attract funding\n\n\u25cf Project funds will be utilized for the intended purpose\n\n\u25cf Meals will be nutritious and healthy for beneficiaries\n\n3\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cf Financial sponsors will remit agreed upon funds should need\n\narise\n\n\u25cf Groceries and cooking materials will be readily available\n\nConstraints \u25cf Unavailability of chefs\n\n\u25cf Donation failure from Partner Supermarkets\n\n\u25cf Lack of funding for project\n\n\u25cf No attention and smooth resolution to conflict\n\n\u25cf Poor quality meals/food poisoning and allergy attacks\n\n\u25cf Embezzlement of project funds\n\n8.APPROVED FINANCIAL RESOURCES\n\nProject budget\n\n9. PROJECT APPROVAL REQUIREMENTS\n\nProject approval\n\nrequirements\n\nAchieving the following represents project success. Project\n\noutcome is collectively tracked and monitored by the Project team:\n\n\u25cf Amount mobilized:  36,000 EUR\n\n\u25cf Number of volunteers (Servers) recruited: At least 46\n\n\u25cf Number of Chefs engaged: At least 7\n\n\u25cf First meal service:  2-oct.-23\n\n\u25cf Last meal service: 31-oct.-23\n\n\u25cf Number of Meals served per evening meal service: 200\n\n\u25cf Timely delivery of meals to beneficiaries: Delay of no more\n\nthan 10 minutes\n\n\u25cf Follow-up phase completed: 15-nov.-23\n\n4\n\n\n", "cloud_doc_url": null}, {"matched_text": "\u301022\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 946, "end_idx": 957, "alt": null, "type": "file", "name": "PMPFINAL.pdf", "id": "file-rqGNHp7RkbtAhSgAxbwEy8Zg", "source": "my_files", "snippet": "\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nProject Management Plan\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nCapstone Project Work\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nApril 2022\n\nCapstone project by:\n\nMary Grace HATCHER\n\nAlexis LINDSAY\n\nMichael P. MENDY\n\nOliver L. OLIVEROS\n\nCatelijne RIBBINK\n\nPROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nTRECCE Project\n\n1\n\n\n\nRome, 23 January 2023\n\nVERSION\n\nVersion\n\n#\n\nRealized by Revision\n\ndate\n\nApproved\n\nby\n\nApproval\n\ndate\n\nRationale\n\n1.0 MGH 09/12/2022 OO 10/12/2022 First draft of PMP\n\n1.1 AL 20/01/2023 MGH 20/01/2023 Edit to Cost management\n\n1.2 OO 20/01/2023 MM 20/01/2023 Edit to Stakeholder\n\nengagement\n\n1.3 OO 21/01/2023 CR/MGH 22/01/2023 Finalizing PMP\n\n1.4 AL 23/01/2023 Finalizing PMP\n\nPage 2 of 25\n\n\n\nTABLE OF CONTENTS\n\nSummary\n\n1 INTRODUCTION 4\n\n2 SCOPE MANAGEMENT 6\n\n3 COST MANAGEMENT 11\n\n4 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT 12\n\n5 PROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT 13\n\n6 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT 14\n\n7 RISK MANAGEMENT AND REGISTER 15\n\n8 STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT 16\n\nAPPENDIX A: PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN APPROVAL 21\n\nAPPENDIX B: ANNEX DIRECTORY 22\n\nAPPENDIX C: GLOSSARY 24\n\nAPPENDIX D: EXTERNAL DOCUMENTATION AND RESOURCES 25\n\nPage 3 of 25\n\n\n\n1 INTRODUCTION\n\n1.1 PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nThe following project management plan was completed for the project titled \u201cTrecce\u201d. It\n\nwas developed based on acceptance of the related Project Charter and defines how this\n\nproject will be executed, monitored, controlled, and closed. This PMP is addressed to all\n\nstakeholders, including the management team, all sponsors, and the project team. Trecce\n\naims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to take part in a month-long pilot event at Mensa\n\nGiovanni Paolo II to offer nutritious meals to the economically disadvantaged while\n\nreducing food waste and fostering community engagement. The name Trecce, meaning\n\nbraids in Italian, derives from the intertwined connection the kitchen, chefs, and\n\ncommunity will have during this project.\n\nPage 4 of 25\n\n\n\n1.2 ASSUMPTIONS AND CONSTRAINTS\n\nThe Assumption and Constraints matrix is a very crucial component of the Risk\n\nManagement Plan. It is very important in forecasting, which is important in building a\n\nproject vision, and identifying project deliverables. Constraints on the other hand could\n\nserve as potential risks if not well managed. The matrix can serve as a guide to the\n\nProject Management Team in identifying all known risks.\n\nPlease refer to the Assumption and Constraints matrix for a detailed description of all\n\nregistered project assumptions and constraints. The matrix can be found in the Risk\n\nManagement Plan folder.\n\nSee Annex 1:  Assumption and constraints\n\nPage 5 of 25\n\n\n\n2 SCOPE MANAGEMENT\n\n2.1 REQUIREMENTS DOCUMENTATION\n\nThe requirements of Trecce include all needs to lead to a successful food service for\n\nbeneficiaries. These include acquiring the needed stakeholders, having an adequate\n\nlocation for food preparation and service, providing schedules to stakeholders, and the\n\nmeans to analyze program success.\n\n2.2 REQUIREMENTS TRACEABILITY MATRIX\n\nSee Annex 2: Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\n2.3 WORK BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE\n\nThe Trecce Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) categorizes all work needed to complete\n\nthe project and represents 100% of the scope. The WBS is broken down into the\n\nfollowing format:\n\n1. Project Management\n\n1.1. Execution\n\n1.1.1. Communication Plan Execution\n\n1.1.2. Project Work Execution\n\n1.1.3. Risk Response Execution\n\n1.2. Monitoring &amp; Controlling\n\n1.2.1. Risk Monitoring\n\n1.2.2. Schedule &amp; Milestone Controlling\n\n1.2.3. Cost monitoring\n\n1.3. Close\n\n1.3.1. Project Close Documents\n\n1.3.2. Project Close\n\n2. Planning\n\n2.1. Procurement\n\n2.1.1. Food/service supplies\n\n2.1.2. Transportation for food/materials\n\n2.2. Schedule\n\n2.2.1. KPI analyzation\n\n5.2.2. Feedback analyzation\n\n5.2.3. Feedback report\n\n5.3. Milestone Review Meeting\n\nSee Annex 3:  WBS Dictionary\n\nSee Annex 4: ProjectLibre WBS\n\n2.3.1 CHANGE MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIf any stakeholder believes a change to the project scope or schedule is necessary, they\n\nPage 7 of 25\n\n\n\nwill be required to complete the Trecce Change Request Form. Once completed, they will\n\nneed to email this form to the project management team, indicated in the project charter.\n\nAt that time, the project management team will review the request and determine if the\n\nchange is approved or denied, completing any research on the change as needed. If\n\napproved, the project management team will be responsible for informing the affected\n\nstakeholders and updating any related project documents such as the schedule, activity\n\nlist, risk register, responsibility assignment matrix, or any document the PM team deems\n\naffected. If the request is denied, the PM team should respond to the stakeholder who\n\nrequested the change, indicating the reason for the denial.\n\nSee Annex 5: Change Request Form\n\n2.4 PROJECT SCHEDULE MANAGEMENT\n\nThe project schedule has been broken into the following phases: planning, recruitment, a\n\nmonth of service, and a post-service-month evaluation. The timeline for each phase\n\ndiffers due to project work needs, the man hours needed to complete the phase, observed\n\nholidays in Rome, and being mindful of our external stakeholders&#x27; schedules.\n\nDuring the planning phase, the main tasks will include procurement of materials,\n\nscheduling for the month of service, and food kitchen logistics. The timeline for this\n\nphase starts three months before the month of service and will last until the end of\n\nSeptember. As chefs and partners will dictate planning details, a lot of the work in this\n\nphase will occur after recruitment.\n\nThe recruitment of partners has already started in September of 2022. As Trecce\n\nrelies on donors to fund the project, it is important to receive around 50% of our\n\ndonation goal before the kickoff meeting on May 2, 2023. Therefore, we felt the urgency\n\nto start requesting donations as soon as possible. The recruitment of chefs will start at\n\nthe project kickoff and last until June 30, 2023. Holding this recruitment early on allows\n\nfor the most preparation of schedules and planning. Volunteers will start to be recruited\n\nonce marketing materials are launched and can sign up all the way up to the month of\n\nservice.\n\nThe timeline for the month of service includes all activities needed to conduct a\n\ndinner service successfully. Dinner service days include Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and\n\nPage 8 of 25\n\n\n\nThursdays. The food delivery will take place on Mondays, Tuesdays, and Wednesdays,\n\none day before the meal service, to ensure our chefs have time to properly inspect the\n\ndonated food, determine a menu, and request any food items that need to be bought to\n\ncomplete the meal.\n\nFor the post-service-month evaluation, the goal is to understand whether or not this\n\npilot program has been successful or not. The schedule includes time to hear the\n\nopinions of chefs, partners, volunteers, and beneficiaries to understand the program&#x27;s\n\npros and cons. Once all data is collected, the project management team will analyze this\n\ndata and compile a report stating their opinion.\n\n2.4.1 ACTIVITY LIST AND ATTRIBUTES\n\nThe Trecce activity list encompasses all activities that must be completed in order for\n\nthe project to be successful. These were developed from the Work Breakdown Structure\n\nand should include 100% of the project work. Included in the activity list are the activity\n\nID, activity Name, WBS ID, predecessor and successor activities, logical relationship\n\nindicators, leads/lags, the imposed deadline, and the location where the activity will take\n\nplace. The project management team is responsible for monitoring the activity list and\n\nmaking any necessary updates during the project lifecycle.\n\nSee Annex 7: Activity List\n\n2.4.2 MILESTONE LIST\n\nMilestone Deadline\n\nGaining committed donors to fund project at 50% 02/05/23\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for chefs. 30/06/2023\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for partners 30/06/2023\n\nMeeting recruitment requirements for volunteers 29/09/23\n\nThe first meal service 02/10/2023\n\nThe last meal service 31/10/2023\n\nAll expected feedback is collected for analysis 07/11/2023\n\nCompleting the follow-up phase tasks 15/11/2023\n\nSee Annex 8: Milestones\n\n2.4.3 PROJECT SCHEDULE\n\nSee Annex 6: ProjectLibre Gantt Chart\n\nSee Annex 7: Activity list\n\nPage 9 of 25\n\nhttps://drive.google.com/file/d/1KEQKckZ4wXzWammYTsR6mjKu65fmn_an/view?usp=share_link\n\n\nSee Annex 3:  WBS Dictionary\n\nSee Annex 21: Day of Service Timeline\n\nPage 10 of 25\n\n\n\n3 COST MANAGEMENT\n\n3.1 BUDGET &amp; SCHEDULE OF EXPENSES\n\nAt the start of planning we assume that 50% of the project funding has been secured.\n\nFundraising activities will continue throughout the project. In addition, as this is a\n\ncharitable endeavor, the project management team has agreed to donate 60% of their\n\nsalary toward the project. The schedule of funding partners with donation amount, along\n\nwith a complete schedule of expenses and contingency funding amounts to be found in\n\nthe annex.\n\nSee Annex 9: Budget and Schedule of expenses\n\nPage 11 of 25\n\n\n\n4 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT\n\n4.1 PROCUREMENT AND QUALITY MANAGEMENT PLAN OVERVIEW\n\nThe Trecce Procurement Management Plan aims to define the project\u2019s procurement and\n\nquality management process. The plan will set out the procurement and quality\n\nmanagement guidelines, define the risks associated with the procurement and quality\n\nmanagement strategy, and suggest the strategy for mitigating those risks. Specifically,\n\nthe Procurement Management Plan will define the following:\n\n\u25cf Project procurement partners and donating partners\n\n\u25cf Quality and procurement work breakdown structures (WBSs)\n\n\u25cf Establishing partner deliverables and deadlines\n\n\u25cf Which items are to be procured via direct purchase, pricing, and timelines\n\n\u25cf Determining material costs \n\n\u25cf Risks associated with procurement management\n\n\u25cf How procurement risks will be mitigated\n\n\u25cf How procurement is coordinated with project scope, budget, and schedule \n\n\u25cf Inventory and Quality Assessment Log Template\n\n\u25cf Quality management criteria\n\n\u25cf Specify all constraints pertaining to procurement\n\n\u25cf Performance metrics for procurement activities\n\nPlease refer to Annex 10 for the complete Trecce Procurement and Quality Management\n\nPlan.\n\nSee Annex 10: Trecce - Procurement and Quality Management Plan\n\nSee Annex 11: Inventory and Quality Assessment Log\n\nPage 12 of 25\n\n\n\n5 PROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT\n\nThe Resource Management Plan defines the approach to identify, acquire, and manage\n\nthe human and physical resources needed for the Trecce project. Resources are key\n\ncomponents of any project. Therefore, successfully identifying all the required human\n\nand material resources required for this endeavor is fundamental. The Resource\n\nManagement Plan also encompasses the Team Charter, a key document that outlines\n\nteam members&#x27; roles and responsibilities, team values, agreements, and operating\n\nguidelines. Please refer to the Resource Management Plan for a detailed description of all\n\nresources identified, how they will be managed and utilized for project success, and all\n\nnecessary information on the Team Charter.\n\nSee Annex 12:  Project Resource Management Plan\n\n5.1 RESPONSIBILITY ASSIGNMENT MATRIX\n\nThe Responsibility Assignment Matrix is a key component of the Resource Management\n\nPlan, which is required to inform all project team members on the assignment of project\n\ntasks/activities. This matrix details each project work activity, clearly indicating the\n\nhuman resource responsible of performing specific project activity/s, who is accountable\n\nfor its success or failure, who is to be consulted before the activity is conducted, and who\n\nis to be informed. The Trecce Project Team chose the RASCI matrix as opposed to the\n\nRASCI matrix because of the support component in the former. The support component\n\nis vital to this project as this is a social endeavor based on humanitarian ideals; therefore,\n\nteamwork, collaboration, and support are highly emphasized for all stakeholders\n\ninvolved to boost the chances of project success. Please refer to the Responsibility\n\nAssignment Matrix for a detailed description of all project activities and assignments.\n\nSee Annex 13: RASCI Matrix\n\nPage 13 of 25\n\n\n\n6 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT\n\nCommunication is critical in any project, not only for involving the stakeholders and\n\nincreasing stakeholder engagement but also to avoid potential mistakes caused by\n\nmiscommunication. For this project, we have established the following communicational\n\npillars that played a central role in our communication plan: transparency, to create a\n\nsafe space, clarity, and a safe approach to handling personal information. With these\n\npillars in mind, we have tried to communicate successfully with our target audience and\n\nall involved stakeholders. We have used a tailored approach to communicate with\n\nstakeholders, partners, volunteers, etc. This is accomplished through using different\n\ncommunication tools per group in order to communicate as well as possible. All the\n\nspecific information on which tactics and tools were used per group and a more detailed\n\nexplanation of our communication plan can be found in the following document.\n\nSee Annex 14: Communications Plan\n\n6.1 PROJECT COMMUNICATIONS MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIn the communication matrix, we have provided an overview of the outgoing\n\ncommunication stream. The table includes the information we provide, the recipient, the\n\ncommunication method, the frequency but also the person in charge of our project team.\n\nThe table also includes the assumptions and constraints we foresee for the information\n\nprovided.\n\nSee Annex 15: Communication Matrix\n\nSee Annex 22: Communication Pillars\n\nPage 14 of 25\n\n\n\n7 RISK MANAGEMENT AND REGISTER\n\nA project risk is any foreseen or unknown issue that can potentially have a positive or\n\nnegative impact on the project. The Trecce Project Team successfully worked with the\n\nrelevant stakeholders in identifying all known project risks. Mitigation strategies have\n\nbeen clearly defined in the risk matrix. Likewise, the recommended contingency action\n\nwill be utilized should the risk occur. Contingency plans have been put in place to\n\naddress any future unforeseen risk or residual risks. The importance of this matrix to\n\nproject success cannot be overemphasized, as risks can be quantified and calculated to\n\ndetermine the financial impact they could pose to the project. This tool is vital in tracking\n\nand managing all risks to mitigate, eliminate, or exploit any risk.\n\nSee Annex 16: Risk Register\n\n7.1 ISSUE LOG\n\nThe Issue Log is crucial during project execution to track and document all issues\n\nthat may arise during the course of the project. This matrix is important in detailing and\n\nassigning issues to individuals and setting a due date for the successful resolution of\n\nissues. This document will help the Trecce Project Team to monitor, assign, and solve\n\nissues before they potentially grow into constraints or risks for the project.\n\nSee Annex 17:  Issue Log matrix\n\nPage 15 of 25\n\n\n\n8 STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project is to become\n\nsuccessful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of interacting with actors involved in\n\nand impacted by a project. It is particularly important to a project as its completion often\n\ndepends on how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the Coordinator and other\n\nstaff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo II who are directly involved in the daily\n\noperations and management of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the Mensa\u2019s feeding program.\n\nIn between are the different service providers as well as range of volunteers involved in\n\nthe project, i.e., volunteer chefs and servers, current partners supporting the feeding\n\nprogram (i.e., Comune di Roma and the local church) and new partners providing funds\n\nand other resources mobilized for the project and the project team.\n\nPage 16 of 25\n\n\n\n8.1 PROJECT TRECCE KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nMensa Caritas Diocesana &quot;Giovanni Paolo II&quot; Coordinator and staff. Carlo\n\nVirtu is Mensa&#x27;s Coordinator. As the key decision maker in Mensa, his leadership and\n\nbuy-in are crucial to successfully rolling out the project. At Mensa, he is responsible for\n\nCoordinating all activities of the Food Kitchen, reporting, and liaison with stakeholders.\n\nHe is ably supported by a team composed of an Assistant Coordinator (Simon\n\nEsuperanzi), an Administrative Officer (Massimo Ceccarelli), and a Cleaning/\n\nOrganization Staff (Brenda Longo). This team, in particular its Coordinator, is contacted\n\nand consulted right from the very start of the project where the Trecce Project concept\n\nwas presented. After listening to and taking into account their inputs, the overall project\n\nidea was revised, and from which the overall work plan and budget were developed. The\n\nteam is obviously very much involved in the pilot project implementation and in\n\nevaluating its effectiveness after completing the pilot phase. It is important that\n\ninteraction with this group is carried out in person, with clear agreements documented in\n\nwriting to avoid any misunderstanding and miscommunication.\n\nComune di Roma and Caritas Roma. As the two organizations supporting the\n\ncurrent feeding program at Mensa, it is important that the Trecce project builds on the\n\nongoing program they currently support. As with the Mensa team, both Comune and\n\nCaritas are contacted and consulted right from the very start of the project, where the\n\nTrecce Project concept was presented. Their inputs and suggestions are integrated into\n\nthe design of the project, and their full support moving forward was solicited. The Project\n\nteam assures the Comune and Caritas that the Trecce Project will build on the current\n\nfeeding program that they are supporting and that any changes to be made are only to\n\nimprove it. Regular and open communication, both verbal and written, takes place\n\nregularly, with meeting agreements documented.\n\nProject beneficiaries. The project is designed with the economically disadvantaged in\n\nmind, i.e., hundreds of people who rely on free meals provided by Mensa. But free meals\n\ndo not need to be less nutritious. Trecce Project is all about serving nutritious meals\n\nprepared by volunteer chefs/student chefs. Feedback from the beneficiaries will be\n\nsolicited verbally during or right after each meal service.\n\nPage 17 of 25\n\n\n\nFood transport service provider. Transport provider LogTech SRL is mobilized to\n\nensure timely delivery of food items/ingredients, either donated or purchased. They are\n\nbriefed as regards the project, emphasizing the critical role they play in avoiding delays\n\nand smooth execution of daily plans.\n\nToo Good To Go, Glovo, and Food for Good. These partners are all engaged in\n\nreducing food waste and in making nutritious food accessible. Trecce project partners\n\nwith them to provide ready meals to the Trecce project in case of insufficient meals\n\nduring project execution. Also, should there be excess food items prepared, they are also\n\nmobilized to deliver to other individuals or other charities in Rome. Terms of\n\ncollaboration with these partners are spelled out in a Partnership Agreement which is\n\ndiscussed and agreed upon with them following the presentation and discussion of the\n\nTrecce Project prior to its kickoff.\n\nPartner chefs, Culinary Schools, and Chef associations. There is no shortage of\n\nfood practitioners in Rome. Foremost of these are various restaurant chefs, culinary\n\nschools, and chef associations in the city. With thousands of members among\n\nprofessional chefs and restaurateurs (in the case of associations) and future chefs and\n\nteachers (in the case of culinary schools), these establishments is a rich pool of volunteer\n\nchefs, teachers, and students whose values and passion are fully aligned with the\n\nphilosophy of the Trecce project, i.e., making nutritious food available while reducing\n\nfood loss and waste. Chef associations are solicited to entice and encourage their member\n\nchefs to volunteer for the program and cook meals for the project beneficiaries.\n\nRestaurant chefs who are not members of any of the associations are also approached to\n\nvolunteer as well. In the case of culinary schools, a special arrangement is explored\n\nwhere the involvement of the culinary students in the project can be counted and\n\nvalidated as part of their community immersion and practices within their own\n\ncurriculum. The Trecce Project will be pitched to these establishments and individuals.\n\nTerms of collaboration are spelled out in a Partnership Agreement that will be discussed\n\nand signed among the parties concerned.\n\nPartner foundations. Foundations are private entities serving public goals. Prospect\n\nresearch was carried out to identify private foundations in Rome whose mission and\n\nobjectives are aligned with the Trecce Project objectives. The various foundations\n\nPage 18 of 25\n\n\n\nidentified as partners for the project operate in Rome, promoting and supporting causes\n\nsuch as community welfare and social inclusion (e.g., ACRI), families and people in\n\neconomic difficulty, migrants and refugees (e.g., Enel Cuore Onlus), health and aid to the\n\nunderprivileged (e.g., Fondazione di Roma), and food security (e.g., Coldiretti). These\n\ninstitutions will be requested, following a pitch for support, to contribute financial\n\nresources to cover the cost of ingredients (should there not be sufficient leftovers from\n\nthe restaurant of volunteer chefs) and project operations (transport, publicity, etc.).\n\nPartner supermarkets. Italy has a law that will make supermarkets donate more of\n\ntheir waste food to charities. The Trecce project will build on this law by soliciting\n\npartner supermarkets (Conad, Coop, Carrefour, Tuodis) to donate unsold perishable\n\nitems (e.g., fruits, vegetables, and other ingredients) that are still suitable for\n\nconsumption through the project. This contributes to minimizing their waste while\n\nimproving their community involvement and enhancing their corporate social\n\nresponsibility. The supermarket branches identified are those within close vicinity of the\n\nMensa in order to minimize transport but also for further visibility of the supermarket as\n\nwell. The Trecce project will be presented to the management of the supermarket\n\nbranches identified. The terms and conditions of their involvement are specified in a\n\nPartnership Agreement that is discussed, agreed upon, and signed by concerned parties.\n\nVolunteer servers. Trecce Project will rely on a set of volunteer servers of different\n\nprofiles building on their high level of social and ecological awareness and sense of\n\nservice (Profile 1); on their interest to spend available and gain insights from their\n\nexperience while at the same time giving them a sense of worth through this community\n\nengagement work (Profile 2); and on their curiosity to discover and know the other side\n\nof Rome while giving them an opportunity to be part of a community. They will be\n\nrecruited to augment human power needs to help in the preparation and cleaning of the\n\nvenue, keep order during meal service, and accompany/talk with the beneficiaries. As\n\noutlined in the Communication Plan, teasers/flyers with details on how to volunteer are\n\nprepared and posted around Rome. A briefing/orientation session will be organized and\n\nconducted. Volunteer Agreement/Consent that spells out the work that needs to be\n\ncarried out, roles and responsibilities as volunteer servers, as well as service schedules,\n\nare prepared, presented, and discussed with the volunteers.\n\nPage 19 of 25\n\n\n\nVisibility/outreach partners (SDG2Hub, Eataly, Mercato Centrale Roma).\n\nTrecce Project also aspires to inspire other cities to come up with similar initiatives. To\n\nthis end, partners with advocacy groups (e.g., SDG2Hub) will be mobilized for further\n\nvisibility. Likewise, the participation of establishments with high potential for local\n\noutreach for volunteers inc. stall owners/cooks, and individual donors (e.g., Eataly,\n\nMercato Centrale Roma) will be sought to contribute to the project as well in terms of\n\nproviding space to display initiative&#x27;s poster (if appropriate); providing connections to\n\nsolicit chef volunteers; but also to collect any unused ingredients from the restaurant(s)\n\noperating in their establishment. As with other partners, the involvement of these\n\ninstitutions will be requested, following a pitch for support process.\n\nAcross all stakeholders involved, feedback shall be solicited in various ways (via\n\nsurvey, phone, or in-person conversation) for further improvement as well as to assess\n\npossible follow-up/next steps. Also, issues and disagreements, should they arise, shall be\n\nsettled amicably by the parties concerned. Finally, the contribution of all partners is\n\nacknowledged and recognized through posters displayed during meal service (e.g., \u201cThis\n\nevening\u2019s/week&#x27;s meal is supported/brought to you by Partner XYZ\u201d).\n\nThe detailed list of these stakeholders, the rationale for their involvement, and their\n\nspecific involvement/participation in the project are presented as Annexes of this\n\ndocument.\n\n8.2 STAKEHOLDER REGISTER, STAKEHOLDER MAP, STAKEHOLDER\n\nENGAGEMENT ASSESSMENT MATRIX AND STAKEHOLDER\n\nENGAGEMENT PLAN\n\nSee Annex 18: STH Register\n\nSee Annex 19: STH Engagement Assess. Matrix\n\nSee Annex 20: STH Engagement Plan\n\nPage 20 of 25\n\n\n\nAPPENDIX A: PROJECT MANAGEMENT PLAN APPROVAL\n\nThe undersigned certifies that I have examined the plan of the Project &lt;Project name&gt;\n\nand confirms that I approve the approach presented. especially when petitioning for prior learning credits related to professional skills. Comunit\u00e0.)\n\nSponsors \u25cf Caritas\n\n\u25cf Comune di Roma\n\n\u25cf Chefs associations and schools: Associazione Italiana Chef,\n\n\u25cf Federazione Italiana Cuochi, Italian Chefs Academy\n\n\u25cf Food distribution: Food for Good Organisation \u2013 Italy,\n\n\u25cf Glovo, Too Good to Go (TGTG)\n\n\u25cf Foundations:  ACRI, Enel Cuore Onlus, Fondazione con Il\n\nSud,\n\n\u25cf Fondazione di Roma, Fondazione Nando ed Elsa Peretti\n\n\u25cf Food establishments:\n\n\u25cf Coldiretti, EATALY Mercato Centrale Roma\n\n\u25cf Restaurants and their chefs/owners: Glass Hostaria,\n\nRistorante AGER,  Ristorante Cariplo, Ristorante Icarus,\n\nRistorante Manin\n\n\u25cf Supermarkets: Carrefour, CONAD, COOP, Tuodis\n\n\u25cf SDG2Adovcacy Hub\n\n2.
