"finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "file", "name": "PM PLA PERSONAL NARRATIVE.docx", "id": "file-PNEDFbPnloWCSGGqmVaULBzB", "source": "my_files", "text": "\nIn my professional journey I have developed a wide range of project management skills cultivated through various roles that demanded strategic planning decision-making and operational management. One of the most significant learning experiences in this regard was my involvement in the Trecce Capstone Project which was part of my Project Management Certification at Rome Business School. This project although rooted in reality was a planning exercise where I worked on creating a comprehensive project management plan. My role in the project included designing the Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) risk management plans and stakeholder engagement strategies. Although the project was not executed this experience reinforced my understanding of project management methods and tools including Agile and risk management practices which align with the first objective of the Project Management course: developing a comprehensive knowledge of project management methods styles and abilities.\nWhile Trecce was a valuable academic exercise my hands-on experience at CSX Transportation provided me with real-world application of these skills. At CSX I was responsible for overseeing and reporting remotely on rerailment operations during train derailments. This role required me to organize and dispatch mechanical staff and contractors order heavy lifting equipment and manage interdepartmental communications to ensure the timely resolution of derailments. This experience demonstrates my ability to manage complex high-stakes projects under pressure coordinating multiple teams and resources which directly aligns with the first course objective.\nIn addition to my role at CSX my previous positions further contributed to my expertise in modeling logical and administrative skills as required by the second course objective. During my time as Manager of Operations and Data Control at CSX I was responsible for overseeing over 1000 support cases each month. This role required me to structure complex tasks prioritize them based on urgency and allocate resources effectively to ensure timely outcomes. My LinkedIn endorsements for skills such as Operations Management and Project Planning serve as external validation of these abilities reflecting my capacity to manage operations efficiently while staying aligned with project goals.\nMy role as Service Delivery Manager at Jacksonville Transportation Authority (JTA) further demonstrated my ability to organize and analyze complex project management tasks. In this role I managed transit schedules ensuring on-time performance and addressing community engagement initiatives. These responsibilities required me to implement logical frameworks and administrative skills to evaluate and execute action plans that directly impacted the organization\u2019s goals. My presentation on service delivery at JTA highlighted my expertise in developing strategies that optimized both operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.\nAt CSX during the rerailment operations I also had to make critical decisions with wide-reaching impacts reflecting the third objective of the Project Management course which focuses on decision-making methods and their broader implications. Managing derailments involved coordinating between mechanical operational and administrative teams making strategic decisions that affected safety operational continuity and financial outcomes. These decisions had far-reaching consequences from managing human resources in real-time to coordinating heavy machinery and logistics which honed my ability to assess risk and make informed decisions under pressure.\nAdditionally in my role as Premier Affiliate Service Coordinator at Commercial Fire I managed a portfolio of fire systems work orders valued at over $500000. This position required careful attention to the relationships between procedures goods and financial outcomes. The role involved coordinating with multiple stakeholders including vendors and customers to ensure that projects were completed on time and within budget. My decisions during this time had a direct impact on revenue generation and operational success further reinforcing my ability to meet the third learning objective.\nThe final objective of the Project Management course evaluating project management technological tools is another area where I have developed significant expertise. At Acadly during my tenure as a Customer Success Manager I utilized CRM tools to enhance customer engagement and optimize project outcomes. By leveraging these tools I was able to improve data accuracy by 30% and increase user satisfaction by 20% within six months. One of the most significant learning experiences was my involvement in the Trecce Capstone Project part of my Project Management Certification at Rome Business School. This project although a planning exercise was rooted in reality. I was tasked with creating a comprehensive project management plan which included designing the Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) risk management plans and stakeholder engagement strategies. This experience although the project was not executed reinforced my understanding of project management methods and tools including Agile and risk management practices aligning with the first objective of the Project Management course: developing a comprehensive knowledge of project management methods styles and abilities.\nWhile the Trecce project was a valuable academic exercise my hands-on experience at CSX Transportation provided me with a real-world application of these skills long before completing any project management certification. At CSX I was responsible for overseeing and reporting remotely on rerailment operations during train derailments. This role required me to organize and dispatch mechanical staff and contractors order heavy lifting equipment and manage interdepartmental communications to ensure the timely resolution of derailments. This experience demonstrates my ability to manage complex high-stakes projects under pressure coordinating multiple teams and resources which directly aligns with the first course objective.\nMy role at CSX particularly as the Manager of Operations and Data Control further contributed to my expertise in modeling logical and administrative skills as required by the second course objective. In this role I was responsible for overseeing over 1000 support cases each month a task that required me to structure complex tasks prioritize them based on urgency and allocate resources effectively to ensure timely outcomes. In this role I managed transit schedules ensuring on-time performance and addressing community engagement initiatives. These responsibilities required me to implement logical frameworks and administrative skills to evaluate and execute action plans that directly impacted the organization\u2019s goals. My presentation on service delivery at JTA highlighted my expertise in developing strategies that optimized both operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.\nAt CSX during the rerailment operations I was often required to make critical decisions with wide-reaching impacts reflecting the third objective of the Project Management course which focuses on decision-making methods and their broader implications. Managing derailments involved coordinating between mechanical operational and administrative teams and making strategic decisions that affected safety operational continuity and financial outcomes. "my_files", "text": "\nPage 10 of 10 page B36\n\n\n\nInventory and Quality Assessment Log\n\nDonor: Item Item Description Quantity\nQuality\nRating\n\nUse-by or\n Expiry date\n\npage B37\n\n\n\nPROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIn the Resource Management Plan, we define the approach to identify, acquire, and\n\nmanage the human and physical resources needed for the Trecce project. The physical resources\n\nconsist of  equipment, materials, facilities, and infrastructure. The human resource component is\n\ndivided into two parts, the internal and external resources. The internal resources are those\n\nacquired and assigned by the functional managers, in this project the Food Kitchen Coordinator\n\nserves in the capacity to assign internal resources. The external resources are those acquired\n\nthrough the procurement process and could also include external stakeholders leveraged for highly\n\nimportant project activities.\n\nHUMAN RESOURCE CHART\n\npage B38\n\n\n\nTOOLS\n\nThe Trecce Project Team will highly utilise negotiation skills, teamwork, collaboration, and\n\nmeetings as avenues to foster understanding of project goals, set defined rules, and build strong\n\nrelationships amongst all stakeholders. The Team will also exploit the opportunities created\n\nthrough the pre-project meetings to motivate all stakeholders especially Chefs and Student Chefs\n\n(sous-chef) in reminding them of the significance of this endeavour, which is designed to provide\n\ndecent meals to the poor/needy, undoubtedly a common desire we all share as stakeholders.\n\nTherefore, emotional intelligence is one of the key tools we will exploit during our meetings,\n\ninteractions, and communication with all human resources of the project.\n\nHUMAN RESOURCE IDENTIFICATION, ACQUISITION, AND MANAGEMENT\n\nThe Food Kitchen already has a coordinator (Carlo Virtu\u2019), and 3 other staff members. The\n\ncoordinator is responsible for directly managing his team, coordinating all project activities,\n\nreporting, and liaising with stakeholders. The Food Kitchen Coordinator is responsible for\n\nassigning tasks to his team, and the team of volunteers that report to work. His team of staff and\n\nvolunteers report directly to him.\n\nThe Trecce Project Team herein refers to the team of 5 project managers responsible for\n\nproject initiation, design, implementation, monitoring, reporting, liaison with all stakeholders, and\n\nproject closing. This Team is already available to work with the Food Kitchen Coordinator and staff\n\nto implement this project, and execute all tasks as defined in the project management plan to\n\nensure success.\n\nThere is great need for professional chefs to be sourced and invited to join the project. The\n\nTrecce project is highly dependent on these chefs to lead in assessing donated food items,\n\npreparing grocery lists, and preparing delicious and healthy meals for beneficiaries. They will be\n\nacquired through our MoU with the Italian Chefs Academy, Associazione Italiana Chef, and\n\nFederazione Italiana Cuochi. Some of the chefs might come from Chef Christina Bowerman\u2019s group\n\nof associates. KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project\n\nis to become successful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of\n\ninteracting with actors involved in and impacted by a project. It is\n\nparticularly important to a project as its completion often depends\n\non how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the\n\nCoordinator and other staff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo\n\nII who are directly involved in the daily operations and\n\nmanagement of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the\n\nMensa\u2019s feeding programme. PROJECT SCOPE\n\nPurpose of the\n\nproject\n\nTrecce Project aims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to participate\n\nin a month-long pilot event at Mensa Giovanni Paolo II in order to\n\nprepare and serve nutritious meals to the economically\n\ndisadvantaged while reducing food waste and fostering community\n\nengagement.\n\nProject objectives \u25cf Complete 13 days of dinner service\n\n\u25cf Reduce food waste and sustainably source all materials\n\n\u25cf Create a model for continued dinner service at the food\n\nkitchen\n\n\u25cf Foster community engagement\n\nHigh level\n\nrequirements\n\nRequirements needed to implement the project include (1) human\n\nresources (able project team, cooperation of the Mensa Giovanni\n\nPaolo II management and staff, volunteer chefs, student chefs,\n\nservers, partner foundations and establishments); (2) left-over\n\nfood supplies and ingredients coming from supermarkets; (3)\n\nfunding to purchase any ingredients and other materials/supplies\n\nneeded for the food service;  (4) functional/equipped and clean\n\nkitchen where food can be prepared and (5) space available where\n\nfood can be served.\n\nMain\n\ndeliverables\n\nFrom Project Management perspective\n\n\u25cf Project Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Budget\n\n\u25cf Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and WBS dictionary\n\n\u25cf Activity List, Day of Service Schedule\n\n\u25cf Project Milestone\n\n\u25cf Procurement Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Resource Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Responsibility Assignment Matrix\n\n\u25cf Stakeholder Engagement Plan, Registry and Engagement\n\nMatrix\n\n\u25cf Communications Plan\n\n\u25cf Risk Register, Risk Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\nFrom project implementation itself\n\n\u25cf Financial resources mobilized:  36,000 EUR\n\n\u25cf Human Resources mobilized\n\n\u25cb Project Team\n\n\u25cb Mensa Giovanni Paolo II staff mobilized and onboard\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of volunteers (Servers) recruited\n\n2\n\npage D2\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of qualified chefs engaged\n\n\u25cb Partner chef associations agreeing to send student chefs to\n\nthe project\n\n\u25cb Partners supermarket, establishment and food delivery\n\nservice providers mobilized\n\n\u25cf Nutritious meals cooked and served\n\n\u25cf Economically disadvantaged people benefitting from the\n\nTrecce Project\n\n5. The physical resources\n\nconsist of  equipment, materials, facilities, and infrastructure. The human resource component is\n\ndivided into two parts, the internal and external resources. The internal resources are those\n\nacquired and assigned by the functional managers, in this project the Food Kitchen Coordinator\n\nserves in the capacity to assign internal resources. The external resources are those acquired\n\nthrough the procurement process and could also include external stakeholders leveraged for highly\n\nimportant project activities.\n\nHUMAN RESOURCE CHART\n\npage B38\n\n\n\nTOOLS\n\nThe Trecce Project Team will highly utilise negotiation skills, teamwork, collaboration, and\n\nmeetings as avenues to foster understanding of project goals, set defined rules, and build strong\n\nrelationships amongst all stakeholders. NARRATIVE.docx\u2020file-PNEDFbPnloWCSGGqmVaULBzB\u3011\nIn my professional journey I have developed a wide range of project management skills cultivated through various roles that demanded strategic planning decision-making and operational management. One of the most significant learning experiences in this regard was my involvement in the Trecce Capstone Project which was part of my Project Management Certification at Rome Business School. This project although rooted in reality was a planning exercise where I worked on creating a comprehensive project management plan. My role in the project included designing the Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) risk management plans and stakeholder engagement strategies. Although the project was not executed this experience reinforced my understanding of project management methods and tools including Agile and risk management practices which align with the first objective of the Project Management course: developing a comprehensive knowledge of project management methods styles and abilities.\nWhile Trecce was a valuable academic exercise my hands-on experience at CSX Transportation provided me with real-world application of these skills. At CSX I was responsible for overseeing and reporting remotely on rerailment operations during train derailments. This role required me to organize and dispatch mechanical staff and contractors order heavy lifting equipment and manage interdepartmental communications to ensure the timely resolution of derailments. This experience demonstrates my ability to manage complex high-stakes projects under pressure coordinating multiple teams and resources which directly aligns with the first course objective.\nIn addition to my role at CSX my previous positions further contributed to my expertise in modeling logical and administrative skills as required by the second course objective. During my time as Manager of Operations and Data Control at CSX I was responsible for overseeing over 1000 support cases each month. This role required me to structure complex tasks prioritize them based on urgency and allocate resources effectively to ensure timely outcomes. My LinkedIn endorsements for skills such as Operations Management and Project Planning serve as external validation of these abilities reflecting my capacity to manage operations efficiently while staying aligned with project goals.\nMy role as Service Delivery Manager at Jacksonville Transportation Authority (JTA) further demonstrated my ability to organize and analyze complex project management tasks. In this role I managed transit schedules ensuring on-time performance and addressing community engagement initiatives. These responsibilities required me to implement logical frameworks and administrative skills to evaluate and execute action plans that directly impacted the organization\u2019s goals. My presentation on service delivery at JTA highlighted my expertise in developing strategies that optimized both operational efficiency and customer satisfaction.\nAt CSX during the rerailment operations I also had to make critical decisions with wide-reaching impacts reflecting the third objective of the Project Management course which focuses on decision-making methods and their broader implications. Managing derailments involved coordinating between mechanical operational and administrative teams making strategic decisions that affected safety operational continuity and financial outcomes. These decisions had far-reaching consequences from managing human resources in real-time to coordinating heavy machinery and logistics which honed my ability to assess risk and make informed decisions under pressure.\nAdditionally in my role as Premier Affiliate Service Coordinator at Commercial Fire I managed a portfolio of fire systems work orders valued at over $500000. This position required careful attention to the relationships between procedures goods and financial outcomes. The role involved coordinating with multiple stakeholders including vendors and customers to ensure that projects were completed on time and within budget. My decisions during this time had a direct impact on revenue generation and operational success further reinforcing my ability to meet the third learning objective.\nThe final objective of the Project Management course evaluating project management technological tools is another area where I have developed significant expertise. Clear expectations regarding acceptable behaviour\n\nby project team members have been defined in the team charter to help promote understanding\n\nand decrease misunderstandings which could potentially lead to conflicts. All project team\n\nmembers are expected to communicate openly, and in a clear,\n\nconcise, and progressive manner.\n\nMeeting guidelines Meetings shall be held respectively as detailed in the schedule\n\nmanagement plan. All team members and participants are expected\n\nto conduct themselves professionally. Idea sharing, positive\n\ndialogue, and motivation are highly emphasised. Active listening\n\nand respecting each other\u2019s opinion are required of all participants.\n\nMeeting minutes shall be recorded and shared always, and no\n\nmeeting shall exceed 45 minutes.\n\nDecision making\n\nprocess\n\nAll decisions shall be put to voting, and the unanimous majority\n\ncarries the vote. Members are strictly required to accept all agreed\n\nupon decisions, and work on executing all project tasks as assigned.\n\npage B44\n# \u301010\u2020PMPFINAL.pdf\u2020file-7kDm00qNx5CfMEv6nfvUg1bT\u3011\nlife cycle\n\nBiodegradable\n\ndual-purpose\n\nsalad/soup bowls\n\nand lids\n\nThese items will be procured and\n\nmade available to serve as food\n\ncontainers\n\nAvailable throughout the project\n\nlife cycle\n\nNapkins (200 pcs\n\nbox)\n\nThese items will be procured and\n\nmade available to be provided in\n\neach meal package\n\nAvailable throughout the project\n\nlife cycle\n\npage B42\n\n\n\nComputers This resource will be used for data\n\nentry, storage, and report writing\n\nAvailable throughout the project\n\nlife cycle\n\nBooks, papers, and\n\nfiles\n\nThese materials will be used in\n\nwriting, posting and display of\n\ninformation for all stakeholders\n\nAvailable throughout the project\n\nlife cycle\n\nServices\n\nProcurement Procurement services will be required for purchasing of all required\n\nproject materials and food items. \u301015\u2020PMPFINAL.pdf\u2020file-C65p0U7wlAtOirCabrhRqVbX\u3011\nPage 10 of 10 page B36\n\n\n\nInventory and Quality Assessment Log\n\nDonor: Item Item Description Quantity\nQuality\nRating\n\nUse-by or\n Expiry date\n\npage B37\n\n\n\nPROJECT RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN\n\nIn the Resource Management Plan, we define the approach to identify, acquire, and\n\nmanage the human and physical resources needed for the Trecce project. The physical resources\n\nconsist of  equipment, materials, facilities, and infrastructure. The human resource component is\n\ndivided into two parts, the internal and external resources. The internal resources are those\n\nacquired and assigned by the functional managers, in this project the Food Kitchen Coordinator\n\nserves in the capacity to assign internal resources. The external resources are those acquired\n\nthrough the procurement process and could also include external stakeholders leveraged for highly\n\nimportant project activities.\n\nHUMAN RESOURCE CHART\n\npage B38\n\n\n\nTOOLS\n\nThe Trecce Project Team will highly utilise negotiation skills, teamwork, collaboration, and\n\nmeetings as avenues to foster understanding of project goals, set defined rules, and build strong\n\nrelationships amongst all stakeholders. The Team will also exploit the opportunities created\n\nthrough the pre-project meetings to motivate all stakeholders especially Chefs and Student Chefs\n\n(sous-chef) in reminding them of the significance of this endeavour, which is designed to provide\n\ndecent meals to the poor/needy, undoubtedly a common desire we all share as stakeholders.\n\nTherefore, emotional intelligence is one of the key tools we will exploit during our meetings,\n\ninteractions, and communication with all human resources of the project.\n\nHUMAN RESOURCE IDENTIFICATION, ACQUISITION, AND MANAGEMENT\n\nThe Food Kitchen already has a coordinator (Carlo Virtu\u2019), and 3 other staff members. The\n\ncoordinator is responsible for directly managing his team, coordinating all project activities,\n\nreporting, and liaising with stakeholders. The Food Kitchen Coordinator is responsible for\n\nassigning tasks to his team, and the team of volunteers that report to work. His team of staff and\n\nvolunteers report directly to him.\n\nThe Trecce Project Team herein refers to the team of 5 project managers responsible for\n\nproject initiation, design, implementation, monitoring, reporting, liaison with all stakeholders, and\n\nproject closing. This Team is already available to work with the Food Kitchen Coordinator and staff\n\nto implement this project, and execute all tasks as defined in the project management plan to\n\nensure success.\n\nThere is great need for professional chefs to be sourced and invited to join the project. The\n\nTrecce project is highly dependent on these chefs to lead in assessing donated food items,\n\npreparing grocery lists, and preparing delicious and healthy meals for beneficiaries. They will be\n\nacquired through our MoU with the Italian Chefs Academy, Associazione Italiana Chef, and\n\nFederazione Italiana Cuochi. Some of the chefs might come from Chef Christina Bowerman\u2019s group\n\nof associates. They will be managed delicately and scheduled according to availability, to ensure\n\nthat there\u2019s always at-least one or two lead chefs available each day as planned in the project\n\nschedule.\n\nThe Trecce project will also source and attract Student Chefs to serve as sous-chefs. These\n\nindividuals will be responsible for assisting the lead chefs in assessing and preparing meals. They\n\nwill be managed and scheduled as available.\n\nThe project also highly depends on volunteers, local people from the community, churches,\n\nsocial groups, and schools to participate in the Food Kitchen during project events. These\n\nvolunteering contributions can be immense, ranging from cleaning, serving meals, arranging\n\nproject venue, etc.\n\nTEAM TRAINING, DEVELOPMENT AND BUILDING\n\nThe project is a one-month trial initiative; therefore, no capacity building event will be\n# \u301016\u2020PMPFINAL.pdf\u2020file-C65p0U7wlAtOirCabrhRqVbX\u3011\nengagement\n\n\u25cf Catelijne Ribbink, Responsible for project communications\n\nmanagement\n\n3. KEY STAKEHOLDERS\n\nEngagement and dialogue with stakeholders are crucial if a project\n\nis to become successful. Stakeholder engagement is the process of\n\ninteracting with actors involved in and impacted by a project. It is\n\nparticularly important to a project as its completion often depends\n\non how stakeholders see the project.\n\nVarious stakeholders are mobilized for this project, from the\n\nCoordinator and other staff working at the Mensa Giovanni Paolo\n\nII who are directly involved in the daily operations and\n\nmanagement of the establishment to the economically challenged\n\npersons who are the recipients of free meals provided by the\n\nMensa\u2019s feeding programme. In between are the different service\n\nproviders as well as range of volunteers involved in the project,\n\n1\n\npage D1\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\ni.e., volunteer chefs and servers, current partners supporting the\n\nfeeding programme (i.e., Comune di Roma and the local church)\n\nand new partners providing funds and other resources mobilized\n\nfor the project and the project team.\n\nDetails on the engagement of stakeholders in the project (list,\n\nrationale for their involvement, the different \u201casks\u201d, and strategy\n\nfor their involvement/participation are outlined in the Project\n\nManagement Plan and related Annexes.\n\n4. PROJECT SCOPE\n\nPurpose of the\n\nproject\n\nTrecce Project aims to mobilize chefs and volunteers to participate\n\nin a month-long pilot event at Mensa Giovanni Paolo II in order to\n\nprepare and serve nutritious meals to the economically\n\ndisadvantaged while reducing food waste and fostering community\n\nengagement.\n\nProject objectives \u25cf Complete 13 days of dinner service\n\n\u25cf Reduce food waste and sustainably source all materials\n\n\u25cf Create a model for continued dinner service at the food\n\nkitchen\n\n\u25cf Foster community engagement\n\nHigh level\n\nrequirements\n\nRequirements needed to implement the project include (1) human\n\nresources (able project team, cooperation of the Mensa Giovanni\n\nPaolo II management and staff, volunteer chefs, student chefs,\n\nservers, partner foundations and establishments); (2) left-over\n\nfood supplies and ingredients coming from supermarkets; (3)\n\nfunding to purchase any ingredients and other materials/supplies\n\nneeded for the food service;  (4) functional/equipped and clean\n\nkitchen where food can be prepared and (5) space available where\n\nfood can be served.\n\nMain\n\ndeliverables\n\nFrom Project Management perspective\n\n\u25cf Project Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Budget\n\n\u25cf Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) and WBS dictionary\n\n\u25cf Activity List, Day of Service Schedule\n\n\u25cf Project Milestone\n\n\u25cf Procurement Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Project Resource Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Responsibility Assignment Matrix\n\n\u25cf Stakeholder Engagement Plan, Registry and Engagement\n\nMatrix\n\n\u25cf Communications Plan\n\n\u25cf Risk Register, Risk Management Plan\n\n\u25cf Requirements Traceability Matrix\n\nFrom project implementation itself\n\n\u25cf Financial resources mobilized:  36,000 EUR\n\n\u25cf Human Resources mobilized\n\n\u25cb Project Team\n\n\u25cb Mensa Giovanni Paolo II staff mobilized and onboard\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of volunteers (Servers) recruited\n\n2\n\npage D2\n\n\n\nMaster in Project Management\n\nTrecce Project Charter\n\n\u25cb Sufficient number of qualified chefs engaged\n\n\u25cb Partner chef associations agreeing to send student chefs to\n\nthe project\n\n\u25cb Partners supermarket, establishment and food delivery\n\nservice providers mobilized\n\n\u25cf Nutritious meals cooked and served\n\n\u25cf Economically disadvantaged people benefitting from the\n\nTrecce Project\n\n5. In this role Alexis honed her relationship-building and training skills and successfully trained and mentored over 15+ new hires. In addition she earned a Bachelor&#x27;s degree in Business Administration from Metropolitan State University. Later  Alexis joined CSX Transportation and was promoted to Manager of Operations and Data Control where she excelled at data analysis and operations support\u2014resolving over 1000 support cases monthly.\n\nNext Alexis earned her teaching certification and taught English as a foreign language in Prague Czech Republic. Subsequently Alexis gained experience in various industries from public transportation to software development. Most recently as an Affiliate Service Coordinator at Commercial Fire Alexis leveraged her relationship-building and operational support talents to manage a rolling portfolio of fire systems work orders totaling $500k. A proponent of continuous learning Alexis will complete a Master of Project Management and a Master of Arts in Organizational Leadership in 2023. Today after completing the SV Academy Customer Success fellowship she\u2019s keen to launch her career in the tech industry as a Customer Success professional.\n# \u301019\u2020JTA Presentation and performance evaluations of all \n\ndirect/indirect reports.\n\ufffd Job shadow all direct reports at least once.\n\ufffd Review and ensure all direct reports are in compliance with \n\nmandatory events and resolve passenger and \nJTA Bus Operator problems.\n\n\u2022 Act as a community liaison throughout \nservice area and act as the liaison between \nOperations Supervisors and other JTA team \nmembers.\n\nSERVICE DELIVERY MANAGER\nThe First 90 Days\n\n\n\n\u2022 Assist with special event organization and \nexecution (e.g., stadium shuttles, special \nservice requests, promotional 1727887777.843424, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["To register your marriage in Utah with your Italian husband while in Italy and obtain a residence permit, you\u2019ll need to go through a few steps in both countries:\n\n### 1. **Registering Your Marriage in Utah**\n   - **Marriage License**: First, if you haven&#x27;t already, obtain a marriage license in Utah from the local county clerk&#x27;s office. Both you and your husband may need to appear in person to apply, so check with the county clerk for any exceptions (like proxy marriage).\n   - **Marriage Ceremony**: You must complete a valid marriage ceremony in Utah to get your marriage certificate.\n\n### 2. **Authenticating the Marriage in Italy (if already married in Utah)**\n   - **Apostille of Marriage Certificate**: Once married in Utah, you\u2019ll need to have your marriage certificate authenticated for international use through an Apostille from the Utah Secretary of State.\n   - **Italian Translation and Legalization**: You\u2019ll likely need to have the marriage certificate translated into Italian by a certified translator and legalized by the Italian consulate in the U.S. where you reside.\n   - **Italian Embassy/Consulate in the U.S.**: Register the marriage with the Italian consulate or embassy that serves your area in the U.S. This step ensures that your marriage is recognized in Italy.\n\n### 3. **Applying for Residence Permit (Permesso di Soggiorno) in Italy**\n   - **Family Visa (Visa per Motivi Familiari)**: Once your marriage is recognized in Italy, your Italian husband can sponsor you for a family visa to enter Italy. You apply for this visa through the Italian consulate.\n   - **Residence Permit Application**: After arriving in Italy on the family visa, you will apply for a residence permit (Permesso di Soggiorno) at the local police station (Questura) within 8 days of arrival.\n\n### Steps for Residence Permit:\n   - **Documents Needed**: Typically, you will need:\n     - A valid passport.\n     - Proof of family relationship (e.g., your Utah marriage certificate recognized in Italy).\n     - Your husband\u2019s Italian ID.\n     - Proof of sufficient income and health insurance.\n   - **Appointment at Questura**: Schedule an appointment at the local Questura for fingerprints and submission of documents.\n   - **Receive Residence Permit**: Once the application is approved, you\u2019ll receive your residence permit.\n\nLet me know if you need help with any of these steps!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "9da0d661-c973-4b70-add5-878fd554ff37", "request_id": "8cc62ec9cead0e16-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "9da0d661-c973-4b70-add5-878fd554ff37", "children": ["dece6a40-fab0-49cb-bf4a-c08415b8b3d4"]}, "dece6a40-fab0-49cb-bf4a-c08415b8b3d4": {"id": "dece6a40-fab0-49cb-bf4a-c08415b8b3d4", "message": {"id": "dece6a40-fab0-49cb-bf4a-c08415b8b3d4", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727887929.417079, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["No. Im in italy and we were married un utah but now im back. This process is likely key to obtaining a residence permit.\n\n**Mapping out steps**\n\nI\u2019m thinking through how to register a foreign marriage (Utah) in Italy, ensuring all necessary documents like an apostilled marriage certificate and legal translation are ready.\n\n**Gathering essential documents**\n\nI\u2019m preparing to present an apostilled Utah marriage certificate, a legalized and translated Italian version, and identification documents to the local Civil Status Office.\n\n**Requesting and providing**\n\nI\u2019m working through filling out application forms, supplying extra documents like citizenship proof, and ensuring necessary revenue stamps. Afterward, I\u2019ll wait for the Comune to process and verify the marriage transcription.\n\n**Navigating the process**\n\nI\u2019m outlining the steps to apply for a residence permit in Italy post-marriage, including gathering documents, visiting the Questura, submitting the application, and attending necessary appointments."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"finished_text": "Thought for 11 seconds", "initial_text": "Thinking", "parent_id": "b4a6469e-cbb0-4615-886c-02f30519f0f1", "request_id": "8cc6337b9cb70e16-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "b4a6469e-cbb0-4615-886c-02f30519f0f1", "children": ["f70d2cff-0bf8-4699-8f43-b372e1dbf67f"]}, "f70d2cff-0bf8-4699-8f43-b372e1dbf67f": {"id": "f70d2cff-0bf8-4699-8f43-b372e1dbf67f", "message": {"id": "f70d2cff-0bf8-4699-8f43-b372e1dbf67f", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727887957.234674, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Since you&#x27;re already in Italy with your Utah marriage certificate, apostille, and legally sworn translation (**dichiarazione giurata**), you can proceed to register (transcribe) your foreign marriage into the Italian civil registry. Here&#x27;s how you can do it:\n\n### **1. Registering Your Marriage in Italy**\n\n#### **a. Visit the Local Comune (Municipality)**\n- **Ufficio di Stato Civile (Civil Status Office)**: Go to the civil registry office of your local **Comune** where either you or your husband is a resident.\n  \n#### **b. Submit Required Documents**\n- **Apostilled Marriage Certificate**: Your original Utah marriage certificate with the apostille from the Utah Secretary of State.\n- **Sworn Italian Translation**: The marriage certificate translated into Italian by a certified translator, accompanied by a sworn statement (**dichiarazione giurata**) made before a notary public (**notaio**) in Italy.\n- **Marca da Bollo**: Purchase and attach the required revenue stamp (**marca da bollo**), usually \u20ac16, but confirm the current amount with the Comune.\n- **Identification Documents**: Valid passports for both you and your husband.\n- **Codice Fiscale**: Italian tax code numbers for both parties, if available.\n- **Proof of Residency**: Certificate of residence or a utility bill showing your address in Italy.\n\n#### **c. Fill Out Application Forms**\n- The Comune may provide specific forms to request the **trascrizione** (transcription) of your foreign marriage certificate into the Italian civil registry.\n\n#### **d. Processing**\n- **Verification**: The civil status office will verify your documents.\n- **Time Frame**: Processing times can vary but usually take a few weeks.\n\n### **2. Applying for a Residence Permit (Permesso di Soggiorno)**\n\nOnce your marriage is registered in Italy, you can apply for a residence permit for family reasons.\n\n#### **a. Prepare Necessary Documents**\n- **Application Kit**: Obtain the residence permit application kit from a local post office (Poste Italiane) that has a **Sportello Amico** counter.\n- **Registered Marriage Certificate**: A copy of the marriage certificate registered in Italy.\n- **Your Passport**: Original and photocopies of all pages.\n- **Your Husband&#x27;s Italian ID**: Such as a passport or identity card.\n- **Proof of Income**: Your husband&#x27;s proof of sufficient income to support the family.\n- **Proof of Accommodation**: Rental contract or property ownership documents.\n- **Health Insurance**: If you&#x27;re not entitled to public health care yet.\n- **Four Passport-Sized Photos**: Recent and identical.\n\n#### **b. Submit the Application**\n- **Fill Out the Application**: Complete the forms in the kit carefully.\n- **Attach Documents**: Include copies of all required documents.\n- **Pay Fees**: There are processing fees (approx. \u20ac30) and a residence permit fee (which can range from \u20ac80 to \u20ac200 depending on the permit&#x27;s duration).\n- **Send Application**: Submit your application at the post office&#x27;s **Sportello Amico** counter. You&#x27;ll receive a receipt (**ricevuta**) and an appointment date for fingerprints at the local **Questura** (Police Headquarters).\n\n#### **c. Attend Questura Appointment**\n- **Fingerprinting**: On the appointed date, go to the Questura for fingerprinting and to submit original documents.\n- **Interview**: You may be asked questions about your application.\n\n#### **d. Wait for Approval**\n- **Processing Time**: It can take several weeks to months.\n- **Check Status**: You can check the status of your application online using the receipt number.\n\n#### **e. Collect Your Permesso di Soggiorno**\n- You&#x27;ll be notified when your residence permit is ready for pickup at the Questura.\n\n### **Additional Tips**\n\n- **Stay Informed**: Italian immigration laws can change. Always check the latest requirements.\n- **Language Assistance**: If you&#x27;re not fluent in Italian, consider bringing someone who can help translate.\n- **Professional Help**: Consulting an immigration lawyer or a local patronato (free assistance office) can simplify the process.\n\n### **Summary**\n\nBy registering your Utah marriage in Italy and applying for a residence permit, you can legally reside in Italy with your husband. Here\u2019s what you need to do:\n\n---\n\n### **Registering Your Marriage in Rome**\n\n#### **1. Visit the Ufficio di Stato Civile (Civil Status Office)**\n\n- **Location**: Go to the civil status office of the Municipio (district) where you or your husband is a resident in Rome.\n\n- **Appointment**: It&#x27;s advisable to check if you need an appointment. Due to varying procedures, some offices may require you to book in advance.\n\n#### **2. Required Documents**\n\n- **Apostilled Marriage Certificate**: Your original Utah marriage certificate with the apostille.\n\n- **Sworn Italian Translation**: The translated marriage certificate with the **dichiarazione giurata** (sworn statement) and the necessary **marca da bollo** (revenue stamp).\n\n- **Application Form**: The Comune di Roma requires you to fill out a form called **&quot;Domanda di Trascrizione di Atto di Matrimonio Celebrato all&#x27;Estero&quot;** (Application for Transcription of Marriage Act Celebrated Abroad).\n\n    - **How to Obtain the Form**:\n\n        - **Online**: You can download it from the official Comune di Roma website under the civil status services.\n\n        - **In Person**: Obtain it directly from the Ufficio di Stato Civile when you visit.\n\n- **Identification Documents**:\n\n    - **Your Passport**: Original and photocopy.\n\n    - **Your Husband&#x27;s Italian ID**: Such as his **Carta d&#x27;Identit\u00e0** or passport.\n\n- **Codice Fiscale**:\n\n    - **Yours**: If you have one.\n\n    - **Your Husband&#x27;s**: His Italian tax code.\n\n#### **3. Steps to Follow**\n\n- **Complete the Application Form**: Fill in all required fields accurately. If you need assistance, staff at the office can help.\n\n- **Submit Documents**: Present the completed form along with all required documents at the Ufficio di Stato Civile.\n\n- **Receipt**: Ask for a receipt or protocol number to track your application if necessary.\n\n#### **4. Processing Time**\n\n- **Duration**: The registration process can take from a few weeks to a couple of months, depending on the workload of the office.\n\n- **Notification**: You may receive a notification when the transcription is completed, or you can check back with the office.\n\n#### **5. Obtain Your Italian Marriage Certificate**\n\n- After registration, you can request an **&quot;Estratto per Riassunto dell&#x27;Atto di Matrimonio&quot;** (Extract Summary of the Marriage Act) from the Comune.\n\n---\n\n### **Additional Tips**\n\n- **Language Assistance**: If you&#x27;re not fluent in Italian, consider bringing someone who can translate, as forms and communications are typically in Italian.\n\n- **Keep Copies**: Make photocopies of all documents submitted for your records.\n\n- **Check Office Hours**: Verify the operating hours of the Ufficio di Stato Civile to plan your visit accordingly.\n\n- **Contact Information**:\n\n    - **Comune di Roma Official Website**: [www.comune.roma.it](https://www.comune.roma.it)\n\n    - **Ufficio di Stato Civile Contacts**: Specific contact details can be found on the website under your Municipio&#x27;s section.\n\n---\n\n### **After Registration**\n\n#### **Applying for Residence Permit (Permesso di Soggiorno)**\n\nOnce your marriage is registered, you can apply for a residence permit for family reasons.\n\n- **Where to Apply**: At the local **Questura** (Police Headquarters) or through designated post offices with a **Sportello Amico** counter.\n\n- **Documents Needed**:\n\n    - **Registered Marriage Certificate**: From the Comune di Roma.\n\n    - **Your Passport**: Original and copies.\n\n    - **Application Kit**: Available at the post office.\n\n    - **Four Passport-Sized Photos**.\n\n    - **Proof of Health Insurance**: If applicable.\n\n    - **Your Husband&#x27;s Documents**: Copy of his Italian ID and proof of residence.\n\n- **Procedure**:\n\n    - **Submit Application**: Through the post office or directly at the Questura.\n\n    - **Attend Appointment**: You&#x27;ll receive an appointment date for fingerprints and document verification.\n\n---\n\n### **Summary**\n\nIn the Comune di Roma, you are required to fill out a specific form to request the transcription of your foreign marriage certificate. With your apostilled and translated marriage certificate, along with the completed application form and necessary identification documents, you can register your marriage at the Ufficio di Stato Civile. After registration, you can proceed to apply for your residence permit.\n\n---\n\n**Feel free to ask if you need more detailed information on any of these steps or assistance with finding the correct This interpretation often comes up in discussions about supposed advanced ancient technologies or &quot;out of place artifacts.&quot;\n\nThe images, which are found in the temple of Seti I at Abydos, are actually the result of carved hieroglyphs being superimposed over other hieroglyphs after being filled in and re-carved. When the fill eroded, it left shapes that could look like modern vehicles when viewed by the modern eye, but this is a result of pareidolia (seeing familiar shapes in random patterns) and erosion\u2014not evidence of ancient high technology.\n\nIn academic circles, these are understood to be palimpsests\u2014images made by reusing the same space for new carvings. The specific arrangement of overlaid images creates a misleading effect that does not reflect their intended depiction. in the Torah, which is the Hebrew Bible, is a complex one and is often the subject of scholarly debate. &quot;Elohim&quot; is a plural noun in Hebrew that is most commonly used in the singular to mean &quot;God&quot; or &quot;god.&quot; It can also refer more broadly to divine beings or gods in a general sense.\n\nIn the context of the Hebrew Bible, &quot;Elohim&quot; is primarily used to refer to the singular God of Israel. The use of a grammatically plural form to refer to a singular entity is known as a &quot;plural of majesty&quot; or &quot;plural intensifier.&quot; This form conveys majesty, honor, or intensity rather than number.\n\nIn terms of the number &quot;seven&quot; in relation to &quot;Elohim,&quot; there is no literal or original text in the Torah that references seven Elohim in the sense of seven distinct divine beings as part of a standard theological assertion. The number seven itself holds significant symbolic importance throughout the Torah and is associated with concepts of completeness and holiness, most famously in the creation account in Genesis, where God (Elohim) creates the world in six days and rests on the seventh.\n\nThe idea of &quot;seven Elohim&quot; might stem from interpretations outside of traditional Judaic thought, perhaps influenced by other ancient Near Eastern texts and mythologies where groups of deities are common. However, within the canonical texts of Judaism, such a concept is not supported and diverges from monotheistic principles central to Jewish theology.\n\nFor more specific interpretations or theological explorations, examining commentaries from various Jewish scholars or consulting with a theologian familiar with Hebrew texts would provide deeper insight."]}, "status": "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Reading the Bible &quot;literally&quot; can be challenging because the texts are ancient, written in languages that have evolved significantly (Hebrew, Aramaic, Greek), and they contain many idiomatic expressions, symbolic language, and literary forms that do not always translate directly into modern understanding. Additionally, the interpretation of what is &quot;literal&quot; can vary widely depending on cultural, historical, and theological contexts.\n\n### Regarding &quot;Elohim&quot;\n- **Literal Interpretation of &#x27;Elohim&#x27;:** The word &quot;Elohim&quot; is indeed used throughout the Torah. It is a plural noun but most often employed in a singular grammatical sense when referring to the God of Israel. This plural form used for a singular God is typically interpreted as a &quot;plural of majesty&quot; or &quot;plural intensifier,&quot; emphasizing the greatness and incomparability of God.\n- **Monotheism:** The core of Judaic theology, as expressed literally in the Torah, is monotheistic. For example, Deuteronomy 6:4 (&quot;Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God, the LORD is one.&quot;) is a foundational verse affirming monotheism.\n\n### Regarding the Number Seven\n- **Use of &#x27;Seven&#x27; in the Torah:** The number seven appears frequently in the Torah and is symbolically significant. It represents completeness and perfection, seen in the creation narrative (Genesis 1) where God creates the world in six days and sanctifies the seventh as a day of rest. There are no references to &quot;seven gods&quot; or &quot;seven Elohim&quot; in a literal reading of the Torah.\n\n### Understanding &quot;Literal&quot; Interpretations\n- **Literal vs. Literalist:** A &quot;literal&quot; reading can sometimes be confused with a &quot;literalist&quot; reading. The former attempts to understand the text as the original audience would have, taking into account the genres and literary devices used, while the latter reads the text without regard for historical context or metaphorical language.\n- **Context and Genre:** Understanding the genre (law, history, wisdom, prophecy, poetry) is crucial in interpreting what a &quot;literal&quot; reading means for each part of the text. For example, poetic sections employ metaphor extensively and are not intended to be read in the same way as historical narrative.\n\nThus, a truly literal interpretation of the Bible requires understanding the original languages, historical context, literary forms, and intended audience. It does not support the concept of multiple gods within the monotheistic framework of Judaism. For detailed study or questions about specific passages, consulting scholarly resources or academic commentaries is often necessary."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "5ea44db5-7d59-4a6c-9dc1-5fc44bef682d", "request_id": "8cb37ed47b5c4be8-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5ea44db5-7d59-4a6c-9dc1-5fc44bef682d", "children": ["590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6"]}, "590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6": {"id": "590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6", "message": {"id": "590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727692046.584878, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["this torah/ biblical texts schalor says that the literal translation of the torah is giving aliens with advance technology being worshipped as gods and that the god if israel is just an alien or elohim that beat the other elohims like say baal and gained ultimate power. This theory posits that extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in antiquity and that these beings were the gods described in various ancient texts, including the Bible. It&#x27;s popular in certain fringe and pseudo-scientific circles but is not supported by mainstream scholarship in theology, archaeology, or history.\n\n### Mainstream Scholarship vs. Ancient Astronaut Theory\n- **Mainstream Scholarship:** Traditional academic and religious studies interpret &quot;Elohim&quot; and other references to divinity in the Bible as expressions of divine beings or a singular, supreme deity from a theological and symbolic perspective. They apply historical-critical methods, linguistics, and archaeological data to understand these texts within their ancient Near Eastern context.\n- **Ancient Astronaut Theory:** This theory often takes elements of ancient texts out of their historical and cultural contexts and reinterprets them using modern speculative ideas. The theory is not based on direct evidence but on interpretations of ancient myths and religious texts through a contemporary, speculative lens.\n\n### Critiques of the Ancient Astronaut Theory\n1. **Lack of Direct Evidence:** There is no physical or archaeological evidence to support the idea that extraterrestrials visited Earth and were involved in ancient civilizations as described by the proponents of this theory.\n2. **Misinterpretation of Texts:** Scholars argue that the ancient astronaut theorists often misinterpret and mistranslate ancient texts, applying modern sensibilities and understandings to ancient stories and symbols without regard for their original meanings and contexts.\n3. **Cultural Dismissal:** Critics argue that this theory often underestimates the ability of ancient human civilizations to create complex societies and technologies on their own, attributing significant human achievements to external, non-human sources.\n\n### Conclusion\nThe interpretation of the God of Israel and other deities as aliens is a significant departure from established interpretations and crosses into the territory of alternative theories rather than scholarly consensus. If interested in these topics, it&#x27;s beneficial to engage with a range of perspectives, including both traditional academic research and alternative theories, while critically assessing the sources, methods, and evidence each perspective relies upon."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8cb38538de2f0e9f-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "590cf2a7-eb6d-4c2b-bcc7-5b33b97457c6", "children": ["63e8b438-bbab-454a-861a-092f2d213044"]}, "63e8b438-bbab-454a-861a-092f2d213044": {"id": "63e8b438-bbab-454a-861a-092f2d213044", "message": {"id": "63e8b438-bbab-454a-861a-092f2d213044", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1727695037.411834, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Hey how many times has the US or its allies bombed beirut or lebanon?
